title.narrative: COVID-19 ILO COVID support to women in fason industry
COVID-19 ILO COVID support to women in fason industry

description.narrative:
New/additional funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 The proposed intervention will support women in the textile and footwear industry to withstand the negative impacts of the Covid-19 crisis on their livelihood through quick-fix solutions to the financial and economic hardship that they face, via cash transfers in the equivalent of three months minumum salary of 26,000 ALL/month plus 4,342 ALL for social security contributions for 407 women workers, and by promoting a more sustainable solution by preparing the ground for a short-term return to work under safer and improved conditions. The amount to be paid is in line with the GoA measure to cover the wages of the self/employed in micro businesses.
The intervention will develop and disseminate protocols for safe return to work. ILO will facilitate the negotiation of protocols for measures related to the textile and footwear industry and support design of the national guidelines for occupational health and safety measures. Upon preparation of the protocols and guidelines the ILO will provide technical assistance to ensure that companies have an access to recommended safety and health protection measures during the production (protection instruction and reorganization of production protocols) as well as provision of necessary protection equipment and tools that will be distributed to the companies, as set out in the agreed national guidelines. Thus, the intervention will implement Occupational Health Standards and new standard operating procedures in 10 selected factories by securing: • Effective occupational health and safety OSH staff/committees offering guidance to workers, • Putting up signs and posters in the factory that promote good practices on social distancing as well as hygiene and personal protection, • Making sure that the factory is clean and hygienic (including introduction of physical distancing measures in a workplace and use of disinfectants and personal protective equipment). Based on the specific actions planned, the project is expected to have a positive impact on economic recovery and job protection efforts in response to the COVID-19 crisis.

Nya medel/medeltillägg för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Den föreslagna insatsen omfattar ett kontantstöd till drygt 400 kvinnor i textil- och skoindustrin som drabbats av Covid-19, uppgående till tre månaders minimilön samt att stödja en lösning för att textilarbetare ska kunna återgå i arbete under säkra och förbättrade arbetsförhållanden. Kontantstödet ges i överensstämmelse med den albanska regeringens stöd till anställda i mindre företag.
Insatsen ska bidra till utveckla instruktioner för säkert återvändande till arbetet. ILO ska stödja framtagandet av instruktioner för sko- och textilindustring, vilket bl a omfattar facilitering av diskussioner mellan parter, samt stödja utvecklingen av hälso- och säkerhetsföreskrifter. ILO bidrar med teknisk expertis till företagen så de kan leva upp till dessa föreskrifter samt bidra med skyddsutrustning enligt överenskomna nationella riktlinjer. Insatsen bidrar till genomförande av yrkes- och hälsostandarder för 10 utvalda företag genom att: - Utbilda personal inom arbetsrelaterade hälso- och säkerhetsfrågor på 10 företag; - Tydlig skyltning och annan information på fabriksområdet om vikten av att hålla distans, god hygien och säkerhet; - Stödja god renlighet och hygien på fabrikerna (inklusive införande av rutiner för social distans, användande av skyddsutrustning och disinfektionsmedel etc).
Sammantaget förväntas projektet bidra till en ekonomisk återhämtning och förbättrade arbetsförhållanden efter COVID-19.

title.narrative: COVID-19 Supporting the Vulnerable and Deprived Children in Kosovo
COVID-19 Supporting the Vulnerable and Deprived Children in Kosovo

description.narrative:
New/additional funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 Save the Children Sweden has applied to Sida for funding of 1,5 million SEK for "Supporting vulnerable and deprived children with educational and protective/hygienic kits" in rural areas of Kosovo during the period 1 October 2020 until 31 January 2021.
The proposed intervention will focus on approximately 700 families (with approximately 1,400 children and 1,400 adults) who will benefit from educational and protective equipment/hygienic kits directly. These families and children live in remote and rural areas -- including children with disabilities, Roma, Ashkali, and Egyptian children will be supported with didactic and learning materials as well as technological solutions in order to enable access to learning platforms established by the Ministry of Education in cooperation with Save the Children, UNICEF and other partners. These materials, delivered in the form of care and learning packages through a carefully tailored process, will help vulnerable and disadvantaged children to narrow down the “learning gap” with their well-to-do peers. The protective/hygienic packages will enable children and their families to protect themselves and others at home and in the community; it will also support children’s access to classrooms and other learning environments. The Project will organize also awareness-raising activities to inform parents and caretakers – including children – on positive parenting without violence, sharing up-to-date information about COVID-19 and safety precautions, and by empowering them through targeted psycho-social support activities.

Nya medel/medeltillägg för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Svenska Rädda Barnen söker finansiering från Sida om 1,5 miljoner SEK för att "Stödja utsatta och missgynnade barn med utbildning och skydd/hygienkit" på landsbygden i Kosovo under perioden 1 oktober 2020 till och med 31 januari 2021. Den föreslagna insatsen kommer att fokusera på ca 700 familjer (ca 1400 barn och 1400 vuxna) som kommer att ta del av utbildning och skydd/hygienkit. Insatsen har ett särskilt fokus på barn med funktionsnedsättning. Insatsen kommer att stärka medvetenheten hos föräldrar, vårdnadshavare och barn om positivt föräldraskap utan våld samt relevant information om COVID-19. Mer information i den engelska versionen av beslutet.

The project aims to contribute to children’s educational development in Kosovo, particularly in underserved communities and remote and rural areas with limited or no access to technology and the internet, through a two-pronged approach that targets both children and parents separately to create for a holistic solution:Result 1 - Aiding girls and boys from underserved communities in Kosovo in better accessing distance learning, andResult 2- Empowering parents to better support their children through psychosocial support, positive parenting and COVID-19 information. Under Result 1, the project foresees two main outputs in the form of children benefitting from educational kits and children benefiting from hygiene kits, both of which are meant to support children in their access to education.The educational kits will include 400 kits with education materials for children, and 300 kits with e-tablets and 3-month internet subscriptions to help children in remote areas access online lessons. The hygiene kits will include 700 kits with, among other things, hygiene materials, soap and hand sanitizer. Under Result 2, the project again foresees two main outputs in the form of three TV programs for parents and families with a psychologist / psychosocial support expert on psychosocial support, positive parenting and COVID-19 information and other materials on psychosocial support for parents and children.The project’s beneficiaries will be girls and boys with disabilities, those living in remote and rural areas and those from ethnic non-majority communities, including the Roma, Ashkali and Egyptian communities and parents. The target age group for children will be 3 to 15 years old (pre-school and primary school age). A clear and fair set of eligibility criteria for identifying the girls and boys will be designed beforehand, to ensure that only the most marginalized receive kits. Each kit will also include additional awareness raising material for parents and children on COVID-19, which will be designed beforehand. Following the distributions, Save the Children will review the accountability mechanisms in place for complains, feedback, lessons learned and child safeguarding concerns. Any issues that may arise will be dealt with an appropriate manner.

participating-org.narrative: Save the Children - donor country office

title.narrative: Agreement with Save the Children Sweden regarding Supporting the Vulnerable and Deprived Children in Kosovo
Decision COVID-19 Supporting the Vulnerable and Deprived Children in Kosovo
Decision COVID-19 Supporting the Vulnerable and Deprived Children in Kosovo

description.narrative: In response to the COVID-19 situation, Sida supported Save the Children Kosovo to help 1,400 families from vulnerable groups of the society with education kits, e-tablets including internet subscription, and hygiene kits. All beneficiaries were identified in accordance with the proposed plan, so that among the 1,400 supported families, 840 (or 60%) were families of children with disabilities (346 girls, 494 boys), 210 (or 15%) were families from RAE communities (113 girls, 97 boys), and 350 (or 25%) were families from other marginalized communities, especially poor families (166 girls, 184 boys). Save the Children distributed 400 education packages with didactic materials and educational toys to 240 children with disabilities (104 girls, 136 boys), as well as 300 e-tablets (214 of them with internet subscription for three months) to 180 children with disabilities (71 girls, 109 boys). The didactic materials and educational toys helped children from low-income housholds – especially children with disabilities – to engage in learning activities at home. Children are able to use the e-tablets to access information for lessons and communicate with their teachers and peers. Through this project, 700 families in remote and rural areas – including 420 families of children with disabilities, 105 families coming from RAE communities, and 175 families from other marginalized communities, have been supported with protective hygiene kits. Through psychosocial support and information on positive parenting and COVID-19, the project developed and distributed printed awareness materials, and produced and broadcasted three TV-programs – one in each main language in Kosovo: Albanian, Serbian and Romani – and three radio messages in the same languages. Save the Children filmed three TV-programs (one in Roma, one in Serbian and one in Albanian) that promoted the Positive Discipline-approach and provided psychosocial support for parents and families in general. The shows were aired at the national TV-station Radio Television of Kosovo. The programs incorporated a story created by Save the Children International (SCI), which was read to children and also posted separately on social media. A total of 17,607 persons were reached through the three TV-programs. One challenge noted throughout the project was the initial shortage of electronic tablets at the time of procurement due to very high demand. Nevertheless, the distribution was completed within the timeframe of the project.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

title.narrative: Financial Inclusion and technical assistance guarantee

description.narrative: Objectives The overall of objective of the contribution is increased financial inclusion especially for currently excluded groups (MIPYMES with a special focus on women and young) through the introduction and use of a guarantee fund in the sectors of commerce, production and services. The contribution is expected to have the indirect impact to increase the formal economy and financial inclusion contributing to economic development, promote green investments and environmentally sustainable businesses. In parallel the contribution will contribute to the development of new norms in public policy and national financial system that will allow for a more inclusive system with alternative mechanisms developed through the programme. Theory of Change Setting up a guarantee fund, and sharing the risk of lending will increase the lending to other social lenders. With an increased capital and guarantee in the back (with set criteria to incentive that target groups are reached) the social lenders will expand their target group, reach more people and new groups such as more micro and small businesses including women and young as well as increase their knowledge of and hopefully aptitude to lend to these groups in the future. Through the guarantee and TA, PROFIN will promote the innovation of financial products adapted for the target groups and by increasing the access to finance micro and small companies will have a higher probability of surviving and prospering in their business, avoiding to have to go through informal channels with unfavourable conditions. In the long term it is expected that the intervention will increase the formality of the economy and decrease the vulnerability of the micro and small enterprises and with a long term impact of more formal jobs and reduced poverty. To ensure that the goal of increased access reaches the identified target groups and that the micro and small enterprises can make the most of it by having solid business plans and payment plans, a strong component of technical assistance and monitoring must accompany the guarantee. PROFIN, already a partner of the Embassy in the Inclusive markets program, will be responsible and agreement partner to the Embassy in this component. This will include a package of financial education at the loan taker level but also articulation between actors to build knowledge and trust at EIF and institutional level towards the target groups as well as advocacy for inclusive financial legal frameworks at national level. By conditioning the loans to certain environmental and gender standards it is also expected that the intervention will promote a more environmentally sustainable and less discriminatory business climate. PROFIN is well placed to undertake this responsibility with a strong presence in rural areas, trust (at different levels), experience and innovation.

Projektet riktar sig mot den höga informaliteten i den ekonomiska sektorn i Bolivia, den låga nivån av finansiell integration och de svårigheter som mikroföretag och små företag står inför för att få tillgång till finansiering för sin verksamhet. Insatsen syftar parallellt till att bidra till hållbar affärsverksamhet och miljömedvetenhet bland entreprenörer. Projektet ämnar också ha en positiv inverkan på de allvarliga ekonomiska konsekvenserna och svårigheterna för utsatta grupper och entreprenörer i efterdyningarna av COVID 19. Ekonomisk inkludering är ett medel för att uppnå större jämställdhet när det gäller möjligheter och resurser, skapa ekonomiska möjligheter för utsatta grupper och bidra till en hållbar ekonomisk utveckling i Bolivia. Genomförandepartnern föreslås vara PROFIN, en ideell boliviansk organisation, specialiserad på produktiv och ekonomisk utveckling. Programmet är kopplat till planen för att inrätta en garantifond i Bolivia med FOGAL som avtalspartner. För att stödja upprättandet och genomförandet av garantin kommer programmet PROFIN att ge tekniskt stöd. Detta stöd kommer att bestå av olika komponenter inom ramen för det föreslagna projektet såsom; - Finansiell utbildning. PROFIN har lång erfarenhet och kunskap om den finansiella sektorn och målgrupperna för garantin och kommer att arbeta parallellt med att tillhandahålla finansiell utbildning både till familjeproduktionsenheter (UPF) och till finansinstitut angående risker och målgrupper. Detta förväntas leda till ökad tillgång till finansiella tjänster och ökad räckvidd och inkludering av nya målgrupper för de finansiella instituten. -Identifiera och utveckla en finansiell mekanism/uppföljningssystem för att bidra till genomförandet av Agenda 2030 -Studie av det rättsliga systemet i Bolivia för inrättande av FOGAL-landskontor, förespråkande och studier för att ge råd och påverka lagar och normer som begränsar de nuvarande finansiella systemen. -PROFIN kommer att ge stöd till FOGAL i etablerandet av partnerskapskontrakt med lokala finansinstitut. -Övervakning och uppföljning av lån PROFIN kommer att implementera ett uppföljningssystem som rör målen för hållbar utveckling och kommer också att utforska nya finansieringsverktyg och metoder. Projektet kommer att löpa över fem år med en total budget på 9 012 598SEK. Sidas bidrag föreslås i första hand finansiera de första tre åren av projektet med en budget på 5 991 917 SEK. Projektet kommer att börja med en startfas för att anpassa och justera förslaget till en baslinje och till den ekonomiska och politiska situationen.

The contribution is targeting the high informality of the economic sector in Bolivia, the low level of financial inclusion and the difficulties micro and small enterprises faces to access finance for their business. The intervention is in parallel aiming to contribute to sustainable businesses and environmental consciousness among entrepreneurs. The intervention is also responding to the severe economic consequences and difficulties vulnerable groups and entrepreneurs phases in the aftermaths of COVID 19. The Embassy assess that financial inclusion is a mean to achieve a greater equality in terms of opportunities and resources, creating financial opportunities for vulnerable groups and contribute to a sustainable economic development in Bolivia. The implementing partner is proposed to be PROFIN, a non profit Bolivian organisation specialized in productive and financial development. The project is connected to the plan of setting up a guarantee fund in Bolivia with FOGAL as the contractual partner. To support the set up and the implementation of the guarantee PROFIN will be providing Technical Assistance through this proposed project. This assistance will consist of different components such as; - Financial education. PROFIN has long experience and knowledge of the financial sector and the target groups of the guarantee and will work in parallel to provide financial education both to Family Production Units (UPFs) and to financial institutions regarding risks and target groups. This is expected to result in a greater access and a greater use of financing from financial entities, -Identify and develop financial mechanism/reporting system to contribute to the fulfillment of Agenda 2030 -study of the legal system in Bolivia for the set up of FOGAL country office, advocacy and studies to provide advice and influence the laws and norms limiting the current financial systems. -PROFIN will accompany FOGAL in seeking partnerships-contracts with local financial institutions. -Monitoring and follow up of loans PROFIN will implement a monitoring system relating to the Sustainable development goals and will also be exploring new financing tools and methods. The project is proposed to run over five years with a budget of approximately 10 MSEK. Sida is proposed to initially fund the first three years with a total budget of 5 991 917 SEK. The project will start with an inception phase in order to adjust and adapt the proposal to a baseline and to the changes economic and political situation.

description.narrative: The inception report is expected end of June and before this it is difficult to report results achieved. In communication with the Embassy (meetings and phone calls) PROFIN report that consultancy studies for the inclusion of SDGs in the formal financial reporting system (through ASFI), for the analysis of impact of COVID on the financial and credit market are to be finished as planned. Discussions with ASFI is progressing well and meetings have been held with stakeholders such as the vice minister for economy and finance, ASFI, BDP and several IFDs to inform and discuss the guarantee instrument. Contact has been established with the projects financed by the Embassy with UNICEF in Montero, Agua Tuya in Cochabamba and WWF in Santa Cruz to include financial education components in the projects. Field visits has taken place in Montero.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

Kosovo Competitiveness Study will determine Kosovo’s most optimal path to competitiveness by examining the data (facts) and considering various developmental alternatives (scenarios).
The study will focus on involving all the relevant stakeholders to jointly develop and take ownership of an overarching competitiveness study that focuses on: a) Economy, b) Business Environment, and c) Education.
The aim is to draft a comprehensive competitiveness study with concrete developmental plans for improving conditions in the following sectors:
Economy - including standard of living, poverty eradication, employment, economic inclusiveness, anti-monopoly policies, trade competitiveness, openness to trade.
Business Environment - including entrepreneurial environment, business infrastructure, access to credit, investor protections, labour market flexibility.
Education - including access to education, quality of education, human capital.

The Management Development Associates Foundation (MDAF), a Kosovo-based Non-Governmental Organization (NGO) applied to Sida for funding of 2 million SEK to carry out the “Kosovo Competitiveness Study” post COVID-19 resilience, in Kosovo during the period 2020-2021. The intervention Kosovo Competitiveness Study aims to determine Kosovo’s most optimal path to competitiveness by examining the data (facts) and considering various developmental alternatives (scenarios). The study will focus on involving all the relevant stakeholders to jointly develop and take ownership of an overarching competitiveness study that focuses on: a) Economy, b) Business Environment, and c) Education. The aim is to draft a comprehensive competitiveness study with concrete developmental plans for improving conditions in the following sectors: Economy - including standard of living, poverty eradication, employment, economic inclusiveness, anti-monopoly policies, trade competitiveness, openness to trade. Business Environment - including entrepreneurial environment, business infrastructure, access to credit, investor protections, labour market flexibility. Education - including access to education, quality of education, human capital. The intervention’s total budget is 4 million SEK, out of which the organization’s own funding is approximately 2 million SEK (188,094 EURO) and the remaining approximately 2 million SEK (188,060 EURO) is contributed by Sida.

The main objective of the intervetion is a comprehensive competitiveness study with concrete developmental plans for improving conditions in the following thematic areas: economy, business environment and education.

8.2 - Uppnå högre ekonomisk produktivitet genom diversifiering, teknisk uppgradering och innovation, bland annat genom att fokusera på sektorer med högt förädlingsvärde och hög arbetsintensitet.

title.narrative: COVID-19 EBRD Youth in Business in Western Balkans
COVID-19 EBRD Youth in Business på Västra Balkan

description.narrative:
New/additional funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 The program aims to increase youth entrepreneurs and youth-led micro, small and medium-sized businesses ("Youth MSMEs") access to finance and business skills, allowing youth MSMEs to grow and deliver economic performance and a more inclusive economic development in the region. This is expected to contribute to several other social gains such as increased opportunities for employment and income generation and decreased emigration of youth in the Western balkans. The program also entails significant elements that aim to support the recovery following the economic crisis caused by Covid-19.
Through local partner financial institutions (PFIs), the EBRD will offer credit lines dedicated to youth MSMEs in combination with a first-loss risk cover. Sida funding is proposed to cover the capacity building component of the program which will be made up of technical assistance to the PFIs and also access to know-how aimed at participating youth entrepreneurs, in the form of business advisory support, business development and networking opportunities. Specific trainings on digitization, value chain management and environmental sustainability will be included as a response to needs emerged during the current pandemic.Important elements to note in the proposed intervention are also the regional exchange and networking that will be promoted, as well as the intent to engage with local organizations with mandates related to youth entrepreneurship.

Nya medel/medeltillägg för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Den föreslagna insatsen syftar till att öka tillgång till finansiering och stärkt kapacitet hos unga entreprenörer och mikro-, små och medelstora företag (MSMEs) ledda av unga personer. Detta förväntas bidra till att MSMEs ledda av unga människor kan växa, leverera ekonomiska resultat och bidra till en mer inkluderande ekonomisk utveckling i regionen. Detta förväntas också leda till flera andra sociala vinster, såsom ökad sysselsättning bland unga, ökade möjligheter till försörjning och minskad emigration bland den unga befolkningen på västra Balkan. Programmet syftar också till att underlätta återhämtningen efter den ekonomiska kris som orsakats av Covid-19.
Genom lokala finansiella partnerorganisationer (PFI) kommer EBRD att erbjuda krediter som är avsedda för MSME ledda av ugna personer, i kombination med en risk "first loss risk-cover" garanti. Sidas finansiering syftar till att täcka de delar av insatsen som gäller kapacitetsutveckling i form av TA till PFI samt utbildning som riktar sig till deltagande unga entreprenörer i form av affärsrådgivning, affärsutveckling och nätverksmöjligheter. Särskilt fokus läggs även på utbildning inom digitalisering, hantering av värdekedjor och "grön omställning", för att svara upp mot de stora behov som finns efter rådande pandemi.
Viktiga delar att notera i det föreslagna insatsen är också det regionala utbyte och nätverksbyggande aktiviteter som kommer att främjas, liksom avsikten att samarbeta med lokala organisationer med mandat relaterade till unga och entreprenörskap/företagande.

The overall objective of the programme is to increase young entrepreneurs' and Youth micro, small and medium-sized businesses ("Youth MSMEs") access to finance and skills to help them grown their business, thereby promoting youth entrepreneurship. This aims to demonstrate that, when market failures are addressed and Youth MSMEs are given equal opportunities, they can deliver in terms of economic performance and growth, and a number of other social gains. The specific objectives of the Programme are as follows: 1. Increased access to finance for Youth MSMEs. 2. Diversified and deepened financial system through increased capacity of PFIs under the Programme to serve the young entrepreneur segment. 3. Increased access to know-how and development expertise for young entrepreneurs and partnering entities with a mandate to support youth entrepreneurship, as well as increased skills and expanded networks. The expected impact of the programme is more competitive and inclusive economies through a strengthened role for young entrepreneurs.

title.narrative: COVID-19 UNICEF Somalia 2021-2022 tematiskt stöd hälsa & skydd av barn
COVID-19 UNICEF Somalia 2021-2022 thematic support health and protective environment

description.narrative:
New/additional funds to address COVID-19 Sida will support United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF) in Somalia with thematic funding for Health and Protective Environment, with an additional support to the Covid vaccination campagin. The contribution has the overall objective to contribute to:
- That more newborns, infants and children survive and thrive, and fewer women and girls die during pregnancy and childbirth. - That children and women are safer and better protected from violence, exploitation, abuse and harm.
The proposed contribution will contribute to the following objectives in the Strategy for Sweden’s development cooperation with Somalia 2018–2022: - Greater and equitable access to health and medical care, focusing on women and children; - Strengthened systems and institutions that promote and guarantee respect for human rights, democracy and the rule of law; and - Strengthened capacity to prevent and counter violent extremism and radicalisation.
Sida will contribute with 75 million SEK over the period 2021-2022 to the thematic areas, health, including an earmarked support to the roll-out of the Covid-19 vaccination campaign, and protective environment, as stated in UNICEF's Country Programme for Somalia 2021-2025. During the same period UNICEF proposes to implement the equivalent of 520 million SEK from regular and other resources to the same thematic programmes.

Nya medel/medeltillägg för att bekämpa covid-19 Sida kommer att stödja FN:s barnfond (UNICEF) i Somalia med finansiering av de tematiska programmen Hälsa och Skyddande miljö för barn, och ett extraordinärt tillägg för att stödja utrullningen av vaccinationskampanjen av covid vaccin. Insatsen har de övergripande målen att bidra till:
- Att fler nyfödda, spädbarn och barn överlever och utvecklas och att färre kvinnor och flickor dör under graviditet och förlossning. - Att barn och kvinnor är säkrare och bättre skyddade från våld, exploatering och övergrepp.
Den föreslagna insatsen kommer att bidra till följande mål i Strategin för Sveriges utvecklingssamarbete med Somalia 2018 - 2022: - Ökad och jämlik tillgång till hälso- och sjukvård med fokus på kvinnor och barn; - Stärkta system och institutioner som upprätthåller och garanterar respekt för mänskliga rättigheter, demokrati och rättsstatens principer, och; - Stärkt kapacitet att förebygga och motverka våldsam extremism och radikalisering
Sida kommer att bidra med 75 miljoner kronor under perioden 2021 - 2022 till de tematiska programmen Hälsa, inklusive ett öronmärkt stöd till utrullningen av Covid-19 vaccineringen, och Skyddande miljö för barn, såsom de är föreslagna i UNICEF:s landprogram för Somalia 2021 - 2025. UNICEF kommer under samma period att finansiera samma tematiska program med motsvarande 520 miljoner kronor.

The contribution is focused on two areas: health and protective environment Health: UNICEF states that the overall purpose of its support to Somalia’s health programming is to ensure that more children aged 0-18 years and women benefit from quality comprehensive health services and healthy life practices. Programming will, UNICEF informs, therefore focus on strengthening evidence-based planning, budgeting and monitoring for maternal, neonatal, child and adolescent health (MNCAH), improving quality MNCAH services as well as family care practices for health and nutrition and institutionalizing community health approaches. As part of Somalia’s strategy, to reduce neonatal mortality, UNICEF aims – with the contribution from Sida - to provide continued support to evidence-based low-cost high impact interventions to mothers and babies to reduce new-born mortality and still births. UNICEF support includes trainings of midwives, nurses and doctors on early essential new-born care, which UNICEF with Sida support seeks to roll out in two federal member states: Hirshabelle and South West States. Complemented with supplies and equipment, competency-based training will - according to UNICEF - target health professionals, primarily midwives, nurses and doctors from regional hospitals, health centres and peripheral health units (PHUs) to deliver quality interventions for pregnant and lactating women and their babies. In terms of actual activities, UNICEF states that these are derived from the essential package of health services (EPHS) with primary focus to establish quality care targeting pregnant and lactating women and their babies using community, health facility and mobile clinic platforms. This includes: -Cascade (already prepared) various forms of competency-based training to build skills and knowledge of health professionals (midwives/nurses/doctors) and other front-line health cadres (e.g. community health workers). -Provision of new-born care and other related mother and new-born supplies and materials. -Monthly performance monitoring meetings to review indicator trends. -Complementary resources to NGO partners in targeted areas to accelerate mother and new-born health service delivery, emergency referral and community accountability mechanisms (e.g., community health committees). -Develop an integrated health and nutrition “first pregnancy” strategy for UNICEF; and, conduct a detailed assessment and roadmap for gradually supporting the state MOHs to manage managing their own cold chain to enable deliver safe, effective vaccines. -Prepare contingency plans, capacity development and pre-positioning of supplies to enable the different state ministry of health to prepare and respond to regular cyclical shocks (floods, drought)- given chronic humanitarian needs (annual cyclical shocks) affecting the two states. Examples of indicators that will measure progress and results for Health: - Percentage of deliveries attended by skilled health personnel - Percentage of pregnant women who attended at least four times for antenatal care during their pregnancy - Percentage of children under 1 year receiving measles-containing vaccine Protective environment: The humanitarian crisis in Somalia is among the most complex and longstanding emergencies in the world. The protective environment for children has been weakened due to more than two decades of conflict resulting in the collapse of institutions at all levels. The perpetration of grave child rights violations including the recruitment and use of children by armed forces and groups remains a major concern in Somalia. Under the programme for protective environment UNICEF will provide technical support to the Ministry of Women and Human Rights Development and the Ministry of Justice to develop an effective child protection system. UNICEF will support the Government in accelerating the domestication of the Convention on the Rights of the Child through building a stronger legislative and policy environment. The Child Protection Information Management System will be rolled out nationwide, providing case management tools that reinforce accountable services and follow-up. UNICEF will furthermore in the area of child protection/protective environment: -Strengthen the protective environment for girls and boys in school. -Support children affected by armed conflict (including maintenance of the monitoring and reporting mechanism on grave child rights violations). More specifically, the contribution will help to support the retention of girls and boys in school by contributing to a wider safe schools initiative that is being developed between the UNICEF education and child protection teams. The broader program includes the development of school councils, teacher codes of conduct, improved pre- and in-service teacher training, higher female teacher ratios, as well as empowerment self-defence and "your moment of truth" violence prevention norm change programming for students. Examples of indicators that will measure progress and results for Protective Environment: - Outcome indicator: Number of schools and adolescent students (by sex) engaged in a safe schools’ programme incorporating adolescent empowerment - Outcome indicator: % of girls and boys recruited and used by armed forces and groups that have been released and reintegrated with their families and provided with adequate care and services For both Health and Protective Environment UNICEF has provided a results framework with indicators, baseline and targets allowing for a results oriented approach and close follow-up and dialogue on the progress of implementation. Examples of those is presented above under each thematic area. COVAX vaccines and the roll out of Covid-19 vaccination campaign The first batch of COVAX vaccines (300 000 doses) arrived to Somalia on March 15, 2021. The Covid-19 vaccination campaign is of vital importance as a critical public health intervention to help contain further spread especially amongst the vulnerable populations. The COVAX facility will provide vaccines for 20% of Somalia's total population. In this regard, Somalia will receive vaccines to cover 3,134,106 individuals, taking into consideration the population of Somalia being approximately 15,670,529 persons. Each eligible individual will receive 2 doses of the vaccine so, meaning that 6,268,212 million doses are expected to be administrated. In close collaboration with the Federal and State Ministries of Health, UNICEF and WHO developed a plan and budget to cover for the operational costs for the vaccination campaign. To cover the operational costs for the 6,2 million doses that are expected, it is calculated to cost approximately 25 MUSD, or per doses administrated 4 USD. The plan developed includes the following key activities planning and coordination, logistics and vaccine management; human resources; training and meetings; supplies and equipment; transportation; social mobilization and communication; and M&E tools and biometric data collection; intra- and post-campaign monitoring; AEFI (adverse events following immunization) surveillance; and other forms of necessary technical support. The expected outcome of the Covid-19 campaign is vaccine induced immunity to protect against Covid-19, which will protect vulnerable groups and detain further spread of the virus. The proposed 5 million SEK will cover full vaccination (2 doses) of approximately 74 000 Somalis.

tag.narrative: 16.a - Strengthen relevant national institutions, including through international cooperation, for building capacity at all levels, in particular in developing countries, to prevent violence and combat terrorism and crime.

16.a - Stärka berörda nationella institutioner, bland annat genom internationellt samarbete, i syfte att bygga upp kapacitet på alla nivåer, i synnerhet i utvecklingsländerna, för att förebygga våld och bekämpa terrorism och brottslighet.

3.2 - By 2030, end preventable deaths of newborns and children under 5 years of age, with all countries aiming to reduce neonatal mortality to at least as low as 12 per 1,000 live births and under-5 mortality to at least as low as 25 per 1,000 live births.

3.2 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att inga spädbarn eller barn under fem år dör av orsaker som hade kunnat förebyggas. Alla länder bör sträva efter att minska den neonatala dödligheten till högst tolv dödsfall per 1 000 levande födda och dödligheten bland barn under fem år till högst 25 dödsfall per 1 000 levande födda.

title.narrative: Stöd till UN Human Rights Monitoring Mission in UKraine (HRMMU) 2021-2023
Support to the UN Human Rights Monitoring Mission in Ukraine (HRMMU) 2021-2023

description.narrative:
Syftet med insatsen är att förbättra tillsynen på området mänskliga rättigheter (MR) i Ukraina, och då särskilt övervakning och dokumentering av våld och övergrepp som sker som konsekvens av konflikten i de östra delarna av landet.
Insatsen syftar till att öka medvetenheten kring människorättskränkningar bland relevanta ukrainska och internationella aktörer samt stärka deras kapacitet att identifiera och reagera på kränkningar av de mänskliga rättigheterna.

The aim of the intervention is to improve monitoring of human rights in Ukraine, in particular monitoring and documentation of violence and violations taking place as a consequence of the armed conflict in the Eastern parts of the country. The intervention aims at increased awareness of human rights violations among relevant Ukrainian and international actors and strengthen their capacity to identify and react to human rights violations. Among other things, then intervention aims to monitor gender-related human rights violations, produce topic-specific and periodic reports, including conflict-related sexual violence, gender equality with actionable recommendations to alleviate the impact of conflict, inequality, discrimination as well as advocate for a more enabling environment and policy level recommendations.

The overall goal of the project is to increase protection of human rights of men, women, girls and boys in Ukraine, covering the territory controlled by armed groups, Government-controlled territory and Crimea, including in the context of the COVID-19 pandemic response. Specifically, the project aims at monitoring the human rights situation across the contact line with a view to strengthening the human rights protection of people living in conflict-affected areas. The analysis stemming out of HRMMU’s monitoring will also be used to advocate with the parties to the conflict for changes to their conduct and practice, and for their obligation to address violations of international human rights and humanitarian law, as well as providing humanitarian and development actors with information that will serve as a baseline for enhanced shaping of policies and assistance programs. To achieve these goals, HRMMU will work with the UN system, the Government of Ukraine, civil society organisations, the Ombudsperson and her office, international human rights mechanisms and organisations, representatives of the international community, and non-state actors in eastern Ukraine.

title.narrative: Supporting Better, Effective, Sustainable,Transparent SOEs (BEST-SOEs) in BiH
Supporting Better, Effective, Sustainable,Transparent SOEs (BEST-SOEs) in BiH

description.narrative: The World Bank has applied to Sida for funding of 45 million SEK to carry out the project "Supporting Better, Effective, Sustainable, Transparent SOEs (BEST-SOEs)" in BiH during the period 2021-2024. The Project aim is to support Bosnia and Herzegovina’s (BiH) governments in developing and implementing reforms and enabling tools for a modern policy, regulatory, and institutional SOE sector governance framework, as a foundation for improved SOE sector transparency, effectiveness and sustainability. Under this strategic objective, the project is expected to have several indicative outcomes: Entity governments have more granular policy-relevant evidence on current gaps in SOE sector governance and their causes, and the options and tools needed to select, design, and begin implementation of key reforms at all levels; BiH public, media, and civil society have a better understanding of SOE sector challenges, reform options, and safety nets in place to mitigate adverse impacts; local media/civil society are better able to formulate the messages to the public; and the public are overall more supportive of reforms. The indicative budget for the project is 45 000 000 SEK (45 MSEK)

Världsbanken har ansökt Sida om finansiering på 45 miljoner kronor för att genomföra projektet "Stöd till bättre, effektiva, hållbara, transparenta offentligt ägda företag (på engelska: State-Owned Enterprises, SOE) (BEST-SOE)" i BiH under perioden 2021-2024. Projektets mål är att stödja Bosnien och Hercegovinas (BiH) regeringar i att utveckla och genomföra reformer och skapa verktyg för en modern politik, regelverk och styrning av SOE, som en grund för förbättrad transparens, effektivitet och hållbarhet inom SOE-sektorn. Enligt detta strategiska mål förväntas projektet leda till följande resultat: - Regeringarna i BiHs entiteter (Republika Srpska och Federationen Bosnien-Hercegovina) har ett mer detaljerad och relevant kunskap om aktuella luckor i SOE-sektorns styrning och deras orsaker, och de alternativ och verktyg som behövs för att välja, utforma och genomföra nyckelreformer på alla nivåer. -Allmänheten i BiH, media och det civila samhället har en bättre förståelse för SOE-sektorns utmaningar, reformalternativ och säkerhetsnät för att mildra negativa effekter. Lokala medier och civilsamhället har bättre möjlighet att formulera budskapen till allmänheten; och allmänheten stöder överlag mer reformer. Den projektets budget är 45 000 000 SEK (45 MSEK).

The objective of this project is to support Bosnia and Herzegovina’s (BiH) governments in developing and implementing reforms and enabling tools for a modern policy, regulatory, and institutional SOE sector governance framework, as a foundation for improved SOE sector transparency, effectiveness and sustainability. The project has four components. The components correspond to the four constraints/reform areas identified earlier: policy level (main focus), owner level, company level, and reform enablers. The activities under each component were selected according to their relevance, feasibility, and potential for impact, as well as their alignment with government priorities and requests for support, with Government of Sweden strategy, and with relevant World Bank and development partner projects. The theory of change for this activity can be summarized as follows. BiH SOEs currently find themselves in financial and operational crisis. At the root of this poor outcome is an interlocking set of governance weaknesses which cascade from the policy down to the owner institutions and company levels. The reason the companies are unproductive and inefficient is not because they lack resources or market access, but because they lack incentives for performance as a result of the gaps in governance and accountability. Compounding the challenge of advancing needed reforms is the lack of enabling foundations for reform - lack of strong public demand for reform. This project seeks to lay the foundations for improving the health of BiH’s large SOE sector by supporting BiH governments in addressing these key constraints. It will do so by helping BiH governments set in place key governance fundamentals at policy, owner, and company levels, as well as reform enablers. Together these interventions are expected to contribute to two key intermediate outcomes: provide BiH governments with the evidence, options, and tools to select, design, and begin critical reforms; and help build public awareness and demand for reform. Both together will help entity governments to adopt and begin implementation of key reforms to address the binding SOE sector governance constraints. Although the ultimate impacts of these reforms lie beyond the timeline of the project and are not directly measured here, it is expected that if sustained over a medium-long term period, the reforms supported by this project will directly and significantly improve the sector’s performance: they will create a better, and more effective, sustainable, and transparent SOE (BEST-SOE) sector. The Theory of Change graphically illustrates how proposed ACTIVITES lead to expected OUTPUTS, and how those contribute to achieving INTERMEDIATE and DEVELOPMENT OUTCOMES.
The choice to focus on governance aspects is rooted both in extensive literature showing them to be root drivers of challenges as well as in BiH experience. Many SOE projects in BiH in the last few decades, including most donor-supported investment and capacity building projects, have focused on purely technical company-level constraints such as financing for purchase of improved equipment or transfer of technology, while largely neglecting the root governance drivers. The result has been the sector’s continued financial and operational decline over the last decades, despite large capital injections and support. The attempts to address aspects of governance or ownership were generally unsuccessful as they were often not accompanied by critical reform enablers such as strategic communication, change management, and labor management strategies. Without the enablers in place, reforms that were perceived to threaten particular interests were met with stiff resistance and were ultimately rolled back. A notable exception remains the World Bank-supported RS Railways restructuring project, which was seeded with the support of the Government of Sweden, and which invested in consistent strategic communication and a transparent and comprehensive labor restructuring process for that company. Applying these lessons, this project focuses on critical governance reforms needed to fundamentally shift the state of play in the sector. Reform enablers will also receive special attention given the lessons learned about their importance for reform sustainability. Besides the substantive focus on governance, global experience with SOE reform also informs how the interventions will be selected and deployed. Experience from many countries suggests that in challenging political economies like BiH’s the most effective approach is multipronged, flexible, and incremental. The benefits of a multi-pronged approach, which addresses governance constraints not just at the company level but at all relevant complementary levels is that it casts a wide net, and increases the chances of impact. It also brings a wide array of stakeholders into the dialogue, leveraging synergies across different interventions, and allowing strategic sequencing. Applying these lessons, this project will take a holistic approach, addressing governance constraints at all the levels discussed earlier and depicted in Figure 1. Flexibility in the choice or sequencing of activities has been shown to be also critical in uncertain and changing contexts like BiH’s, particularly in light of the COVID crisis. With this in mind, the project will draw on a comprehensive menu of activities (described below) but adopt a flexible approach to selection and sequencing during implementation, to ensure they remain demand driven and responsive to reform openings over the course of the project. Finally, an incremental approach is imperative for the complex and difficult reforms at hand. The project will carefully select and sequence interventions and break down complex reforms into “palatable” steps to set a manageable pace for reforms and ensure that they are sustainable and irreversible. An incremental approach will also facilitate learning by all parties and stakeholders, and allow for easy course corrections as needed at each successive step. To ensure smooth implementation and iterative adaptation to changing needs, the project will be accompanied by continuous technical-level dialogue. Occasional high-level meetings will be organized to facilitate key necessary decisions and follow-up actions.

description.narrative:
Diaspora Investment Partnership förväntas aktivera diasporainvesteringar och bidra till att stärka nätverk, med det långsiktiga målet att bidra till hållbar finansiering och kapital för nystartade företag och MSME-företag i syfte att skapa nya arbetstillfällen och bidra till stärkt entreprenörskapacitet och hållbar utveckling i utvecklingsländer. Initiativet kommer att testas under en pilotfas. Piloten kommer att fokusera på Kenya men aktiviteter som avser analys och partnerskap kommer även att genomföras i Somalia och Etiopien. En eventuell uppskalning avser även fullständig pilot i Somalia och Etiopien (dvs design och test av digital plattform).
Hypotesen är att det finns en informationsasymmetri och ett behov av att utveckla mer formella strukturer för att mäkla investerarrelationer mellan diasporan (samt diasporans bredare nätverk) och MSME:er och nystartade företag på ett hållbart och effektivt sätt. För att fylla detta behov krävs det inte bara att villiga investerare inom diasporan får tillgång till information om möjliga företag att investera i, utan även en försäkran om att potentiella investeringsobjekt har genomgått en viss bakgrundskontroll och lönsamhetsvalidering. Detta bör ske i en riskfri och transparent miljö där risk kan spridas mellan flera investerare. På så sätt förväntas befintliga informationsasymmetrier brytas ner och marknadsutmaningar överkommas.
Initiativet är ett pilotprojekt och Sidas bidrag på 4 850 000 MSEK kommer att användas för att minska risken och möjliggöra för innovation, design och test av tekniska lösningar och verktyg, samt utveckling av nya former av samarbeten och partnerskap. Initiativet kommer att löpa över en 12-månadersperiod varefter det finns en potential att, givet att projektet når framgång, skala upp initiativet till fler länder och diasporagrupper.
Pangea Trust kommer att vara Sidas implementeringspartner. Pangea Trusts övergripande mission är att påskynda och bidra till att skapa förutsättningar för afrikanska entreprenörer att utveckla sin kompetens och få tillgång till relevanta nätverk och kapital för att nå sin fulla potential. Pangea Trust har kunskap om och en lokal närvaro på pilotmarknaden, tillgång till relevanta lokala och regionala strategiska partner (att engagera direkt och/eller som tysta partners) och ett etablerat nätverk inom den nordiska diasporan. Detta anses vara en förutsättning för att kunna utveckla föreslagna digitala plattformar som ska bryta ned den informationsasymmetri som anses utgöra ett huvudsakligt utvecklingshinder. Därutöver förväntas den digitala plattformen tjäna syftet att katalysera ytterligare investeringar. Sida har ambitionen att bana väg för en global uppskalning och vill undvika att projektet endast leder till ytterligare ett fristående initiativ.

The Diaspora Investment Partnership initiative is expected to activate diaspora remittances and networks with the long-term goal to contribute to sustainable sources of financing and capital for start-ups and MSMEs to drive job creation and enhance entrepreneurial capacity and sustainable development opportunities in developing countries. The initiative will be tested during a pilot phase. The pilot will focus on Kenya but activities, including analysis and partnership, will also be implemented in Somalia and Ethiopia. A potential scaling-up will also include the full pilot in Somalia Ethiopia (i.e. design and test of digital platform).
The hypothesis is that there is an information asymmetry and a need to develop more formal and structured means of connecting MSMEs and start-ups that require capital and financing with the diaspora and their networks in a sustainable and effective manner. Not only should the diaspora have the means to easily access information regarding potential businesses in which to invest, but they should also receive the necessary assurances that the businesses in which they would invest have undergone some background check and viability validation. This would be done in a de-risked and transparent environment, where risk is spread across multiple investments, thereby breaking down the potential information asymmetries and market challenges.
The project will take the form of a pilot, and Sida’s contribution of MSEK 4 850 000 will be used to de-risk the initiative, as well as to enable design, innovation and testing of technical solutions and tools. The project will also explore new forms of collaboration and partnerships. The pilot will cover a 12-month period after which there is potential to, if the initiative proves successful, scale to more countries and diasporas.
The Pangea Trust will be Sida’s implementing partner. The overall mission of Pangea Trust is to accelerate and contribute to the creation of an enabling environment, where African entrepreneurs can develop competences and gain access to relevant networks and capital in order to reach their full potential. By leveraging (1) Pangea Trust´s knowledge of and presence in the pilot’s target market(s), (2) their providing access to relevant local and regional strategic partners (to become engaged directly and/or as silent partners), as well as (3) an already established network within the Nordic diaspora, the platforms are expected to not only break down the information asymmetry, but also to mitigate attendant risks. In effect, the initiative is expected to hold the potential to catalyse more diaspora investments through an eventual crowding-in effect. Sida has a long-term ambition to pave the way for a global scale-up rather than creating another stand-alone initiative.

It is important to understand both the short-term and immediate expected outputs from the 12-month pilot phase and long-term development outcomes and impact intended to be supported, would the initiative prove successful and scaled-up. The 12-month initiative entails four separate but interlinked outputs. The initial idea presented by Pangea Trust was centred at the development and piloting of two digital solutions (technical platforms) to “improve the deployment of diaspora remittances and networks to provide investment capital for MSMEs and start-ups” and to “develop solutions within Islamic financing to improve financial inclusion for this demography and mobilize financial recourses from those in the diaspora to which such instruments speak, based on their religion”. During the dialogue and further elaboration of the project idea, Sida proposed to also include activities related to a “diaspora mapping” and the “development of institutional partnership solutions”, seeking to understand better the underlying constraints, success triggers and how coordination and value addition to other similar initiatives can be secured, including also programs and partners already receiving Swedish or other funding/support in the pilot countries. The Sida funding during the 12-months pilot phase is MSEK 4 850 000. The catalytic potential of the initiative is considered high. The monetary leverage during the initial phase is estimated at 1:1 in investments and donations mobilized. The long-term monetary leverage is expected to be much higher as well as other potential long-term results related to MSME development and job creation. The covid-19 pandemic has caused a dramatic drop in remittances. This initiative presents an opportunity for Sida to contribute to the development of sustainable digital solutions mobilising capital for development from and in collaboration with the diaspora. Targeted digitalization of services will bridge a gap between the diaspora and investment opportunities (SME) in diaspora groups' home countries. By this intervention Sida will contribute to the development of digital solutions with high potential to be scaled up to global level, by duplication and sharing of digital code (as a global good) and communication platforms.

title.narrative: COVID-19 HiiL- People-centred Justice: Justice Innovations in a Pandemic Uganda 2020-2022
COVID-19 HiiL- People-centred Justice: Justice Innovations in a Pandemic Uganda 2020-2022

description.narrative:
New/additional funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 HiiL has applied to Sida for funding of 11,853,000SEK to implement a programme titled " People Centred Justice- Justice Innovations in a Pandemic for one (1) year.
The programme aims to increase the number of solutions for people in Uganda that prevent or resolve their most pressing justice problems during Covid-times (more people-centered justice).
The programme will achieve the above goal through working towards achieving three specific outcomes namely; 1. Enhanced access to and use of information and data for/by various justice stakeholders in Uganda on Covid-related justice problems. 2. Increased access to and use of justice solutions for people in Uganda in a pandemic. 3. Increased agreement and dialogue amongst JLOS and Ugandan justice leaders on the enabling environment for people centred-justice in a pandemic.
The programme consists of three components namely i) Justice Research and Development, ii) Justice Innovations and iii)Justice Leadership Transformation. Under each of these components HiiL will conduct activities as follows;
1. Justice Research and Development HiiL will develop and conduct a quick e-survey of justice needs and response strategies during the Covid-19 crisis, it will work together with justice experts in Uganda to develop and monitor outcomes that people aim to achieve when they seek justice during the pandemic and updating the previously developed family justice catalogue to reflect challenges arising during Covid-19 pandemic.
2. Justice Innovations HiiL will improve the local services that are most often used by the population, such as the LCCs and a number of other innovative services. Connecting the LCCs and innovative services with the services by the courts, thus creating effective integration between formal and informal justice, where possible supported online to quickly address justice challenges caused by and during the Covi9 19 pandemic. The innovative approaches will be designed in line with the findings of the e-survey on justice needs during the pandemic.
Additionally, HiiL will provide its previous innovators with seed funding to develop innovations but to also shield the innovators from the business challenges that have been caused by Covid-19 that could lead to their collapse.
3. Justice Transformation HiiL will bring together a broad representation of justice leaders to develop pathways that look at organisational and financial systems, laws and regulations, and ways of working that are needed to address challenges arising during the pandemic.

Nya medel/medeltillägg för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 The Hague Institute of Innovation in Law (HiiL) har ansökt till Sida om finansiering om SEK 11 853 000 för att genomföra programmet "People-Centred Justice - Justice Innovations in a Pandemic” för ett år.
Programmet syftar till att öka och bredda tillgången till olika former av tvistelösningsmekanismer för människor i Uganda, så att de mest akuta rättsliga problemen kan lösas, även under de förhållanden som råder under pandemin. HiiL verkar för en mer individ-orienterad rättvisa (People-centred justice).
Det övergripande målet avses nås genom att arbeta för att uppnå tre specifika utfall (outcomes) nämligen; 1. Förbättrad tillgång till och användning av information och data för och av olika aktörer inom rättsväsendet i Uganda angående Covid-relaterade rättsliga problem. 2. Ökad tillgång till och användning av rättsliga lösningar för människor i Uganda under en pandemi. 3. Ökad enighet och dialog mellan JLOS och ledare inom ugandiska rättsväsendet angående en möjliggörande miljö för en s.k. individ-orienterad rättvisa i en pandemi. Programmet består av tre delar, nämligen i) rättslig forskning och utveckling, ii) rättsliga innovationer och iii) ledarskap och förändring inom rättsväsendet. Under var och en av dessa komponenter kommer Hiil att bedriva verksamhet enligt följande;
1. Rättslig forskning och utveckling HiiL kommer att utveckla och genomföra en online-undersökning angående rättsliga behov och strategier som tillämpas för att bemöta dessa behov under Covid-19-krisen. Rättsexperter medverkar i programmet för att utveckla och övervaka de resultat som människor syftar till att uppnå när de söker rättvisa under pandemin. Den tidigare utvecklade handboken för familjerätt uppdateras för att återspegla de utmaningar som uppstår under Covid-19-pandemin.
2. Rättsliga innovationer HiiL avser stärka och förbättra de lokala rättstjänster som oftast används av befolkningen, såsom t.ex. Local District Courts (LCC). Att koppla samman LCCs och innovativa tjänster med de befintliga domstolarna kan leda till en konstruktiv integrering av olika former av formell och informell rättvisa. De innovativa metoderna kommer att utformas i linje med resultaten av online-undersökningen om rättsliga behov under pandemin.
HiiL kommer även att förse sina tidigare innovatörer med grundfinansiering (seed-funding) för att utveckla innovationer, men också för att stödja de innovatörerna som de tidigare stött i att bemöta affärsutmaningar som har orsakats av Covid-19, utmaningar vilka annars riskerar leda till deras kollaps.
3. Ledarskap och förändring inom rättsväsendet HiiL kommer att sammanföra en bred representation av ledare inom rättsväsendet för att möjliggöra en vidareutveckling av organisatoriska och finansiella system, lagar och förordningar, samt arbetssätt som behövs för att möta utmaningar som uppstår under pandemin.

The general objective is to increase the number of solutions for the people in Uganda that prevent or resolve their most pressing justice problems during Covid times (more people-centered justice). In order to realise this general objective, the programme aims to achieve three specific objectives namely; 1. Enhanced access to and use of information and data for/by various justicestakeholders in Uganda on Covid related justice problems. 2. Increased access to and use of justice solutions for people in Uganda in apandemic. 3. Increased agreement and dialogue amongst JLOS and Ugandan justice leaderson the enabling environment for people centred-justice in a pandemic.

The overall objective of the project is that "Vulnerable children in Abkhazia are effectively supported and protected by enhanced sustainable needs-based social services". This is expected to be reached through the following three outcomes: 1) Community-based approaches to provide quality social services for children in Abkhazia are successfully maintained and expanded 2) Social work and child protection multi-sectoral cooperation mechanisms in Abkhazia are strengthened 3) Evidence base on child protection strengthened and positive social change stimulated

UNICEF har ansökt om totalt 25 000 000 SEK från Sida för att genomföra den tredje fasen av projektet "Utveckling, stärkande och utökning av hållbart grundläggande socialt arbete för barn i Abchazien, Georgien" under perioden Februari 2021 - December 2023.
Projektet syftar till att fortsätta utveckla och införa lokala skyddsnät och grundläggande sociala tjänster, i synnerhet genom utbildning och stöd för socialarbetare och genom fungerande referenssystem med fokus på barnens rättigheter och behov, för särskilt utsatta barn och barn som lever i fattigdom i Abchazien. Under den tredje fasen kommer det inom ramen för projektet även att införas system för alternativ vård av barn så som familjehem. Insatsen kommer även under 2021 inbegripa humanitärt stöd till familjer som drabbats särskilt hårt av konsekvenser efter covid-19 pandemin. Den tredje fasen inbegriper även ett särskilt fokus på att säkerställa hållbarheten i de resultat som redan uppnåtts och som kommer att uppnås under den tredje fasen, genom fortsatt kapacitetsutveckling av nyckelinstanser, samt genom informations- och påverkanskampanjer gentemot både allmänhet och lokala beslutsfattare.
Unicef kommer att genomföra projektet tillsammans med World Vision International och ett antal andra internationella och lokala civilamhällesaktörer som är verksamma i regionen.

UNICEF has applied for a total of SEK 25,000,000 from Sida to carry out the third phase of the project "Developing, Strengthening and Expanding Sustainable Basic Social Services for Children in Abkhazia, Georgia" during the period February 2021 - December 2023.
The project aims to continue to develop and implement community-based quality social services, social work and child protection multi-sectoral cooperation mechanisms in Abkhazia in particular for especially vulnerable children and children living in poverty in Abkhazia. During the third phase systems for alternative care of children will be introduced. The effort will also in 2021 include humanitarian support for families that have been particularly affected by the consequences of the covid-19 pandemic. The third phase further includes a special focus on ensuring the sustainability of the results through continued capacity development of key instances in child protection, as well as through information and advocacy campaigns towards both the public and decision makers.
UNICEF ??will implement the project together with World Vision International and a number of other international and local civil society actors active in the region.

description.narrative: This contribution is intended to support the UNFPA Mali country office in contributing to four outcome areas with five articulated objectives as presented below. The Embassy considers that the outcomes and objectives are clear and in line with mandate and comparative advantages of UNFPA. The Embassy also considers that the outcomes and objectives are relevant for the Malian's context i.e among others the lack of basic social services, weak supply-chain regarding the family planning, gender-based violence including harmful tradional practices. These objectives will be pursued in stable as well as in humanitarian context. 1- Sexual and reproductive health Output 1: Strengthened national capacities to ensure a continuum of highquality essential and emergency obstetric and newborn care for women, adolescents and youth and other vulnerable groups, including those in the humanitarian settings. Output 2: Strengthened national capacities to improve supply-chain management and demand for family planning services for women, youth and adolescents, including in humanitarian settings 2- Adolescents and youth Output : Young people and adolescents, particularly adolescent girls, have improved life skills for informed decision-making, especially in sexual and reproductive health, leadership, commitment and participation in peacebuilding, including in humanitarian contexts. 3- Gender equality and women’s empowerment Output : Strengthened national capacities, communities and civil society organizations in promoting gender equality, women’s empowerment, prevention and care of gender-based violence and other harmful practices, including in humanitarian settings. 4- Population dynamics Output: The capacities of national statistical systems are strengthened for the production and use of high-quality disaggregated data for policy formulation and monitoring of the Sustainable Development Goals to harness the demographic dividend, including in humanitarian contexts.

UNFPA har ansökt hos ambassaden om finansiering på 60 miljoner kronor för att genomföra sitt "Landsprogramsdokument" (Country Program Document) för 2020-2024 i Mali.
Detta bidrag är avsett att stödja UNFPA: s landskontor i Mali inom fyra resultatområden med fem formulerade mål som presenteras nedan. Dessa mål kommer att eftersträvas i både stabila och humanitära sammanhang.
1- Sexuell och reproduktiv hälsa Resultat 1: Stärkt nationell kapacitet för att säkerställa ett kontinuerligt behov av högkvalitativ och akut obstetrisk och nyfödd vård för kvinnor, ungdomar och ungdomar och andra utsatta grupper, inklusive de i humanitära miljöer. Resultat 2: Stärkt nationell kapacitet för att förbättra hanteringen av tillgång och efterfrågan på familjeplaneringstjänster för kvinnor, ungdomar och unga vuxna, även i humanitära miljöer
2- Ungdomar och unga vuxna Resultat: Ungdomar och unga vuxna, särskilt tonåriga flickor, har förbättrade livskunskaper för informerat beslutsfattande, särskilt inom sexuell och reproduktiv hälsa, ledarskap, engagemang och deltagande i fredsbyggande, inklusive i humanitära sammanhang.
3- Jämställdhet och kvinnors egenmakt (empowerment) Resultat: Stärkt nationell kapacitet, inom samhällen och civilsamhällesorganisationer för att främja jämställdhet, kvinnors egenmakt, förebyggande och omhändertagande av könsbaserat våld och andra skadliga metoder, inklusive i humanitära miljöer.
4- Befolkningsdynamik Resultat: Kapaciteten hos nationella statistiksystem stärks för framtagande och användning av högkvalitativa uppdelade data för policyformulering, samt för att uppföljning av målen för hållbar utveckling som gagnar de demografiska skillnaderna, även i humanitära sammanhang.
Programmet kommer att implementeras genom UNFPA: s huvudkontor i Bamako, med stöd av ett underkontor, öppnat i Mopti, som verkar i de centrala och norra regionerna vilka drabbats av den humanitära krisen. Regionerna är prioriterade i den humanitära insatsplanen och av regeringen inom konfliktlösning, fred och utveckling. Statliga organ såväl som civilsamhällesorganisationer kommer att ingå i implementeringen.
Insatsens totala budget är 46,1 miljoner USD, varav organisationens egen finansiering är cirka 12,1 miljoner USD och 34 miljoner USD genom samfinansieringsmetoder eller andra källor. Med Covid-19-pandemin samt den försämrade sociala och humanitära krisen har behoven ökat vilket leder till ett behov av 63,5 miljoner USD. Från den senaste siffran beräknas finansieringsgapet till 26 miljoner USD. Det svenska bidraget på 60 MSEK motsvarar 27% av det identifierade finansiella gapet som nämns ovan.

UNFPA has applied to Embassy for funding of 60 million SEK to carry out its 2020-2024 "Country Program Document" in Mali.
This contribution is intended to support the UNFPA Mali country office in contributing to four outcome areas with five articulated objectives as presented below. These objectives will be pursued in stable as well as in humanitarian context.
1- Sexual and reproductive health Output 1: Strengthened national capacities to ensure a continuum of highquality essential and emergency obstetric and newborn care for women, adolescents and youth and other vulnerable groups, including those in the humanitarian settings. Output 2: Strengthened national capacities to improve supply-chain management and demand for family planning services for women, youth and adolescents, including in humanitarian settings 2- Adolescents and youth Output : Young people and adolescents, particularly adolescent girls, have improved life skills for informed decision-making, especially in sexual and reproductive health, leadership, commitment and participation in peacebuilding, including in humanitarian contexts. 3- Gender equality and women’s empowerment Output : Strengthened national capacities, communities and civil society organizations in promoting gender equality, women’s empowerment, prevention and care of gender-based violence and other harmful practices, including in humanitarian settings. 4- Population dynamics Output: The capacities of national statistical systems are strengthened for the production and use of high-quality disaggregated data for policy formulation and monitoring of the Sustainable Development Goals to harness the demographic dividend, including in humanitarian contexts.
The program will be implemented through the UNFPA main office in Bamako, supported by a sub office, opened in Mopti, to serve the central and northern regions affected by the humanitarian crisis and prioritized in the Humanitarian Response Plan and by the Government for conflict resolution, peace and development. Government entities as well as Civil Society Organizations will be part of the implementers.
The intervention’s total budget is 46,1 million USD, out of which the organization’s own funding is approximately 12,1 million USD from its regular resources and 34 million USD through co-financing modalities or other sources. With the COVID-19 pandemic, the worsening of social and humanitarian crisis, the needs have increased leading to a need of 63.5 million USD. From this latest figure, the funding gap is estimated at 26 million USD. The Swedish contribution of 60 MSEK corresponds to 27% of the identified financial gap mentioned above.

11.3 - By 2030, enhance inclusive and sustainable urbanization and capacity for participatory, integrated and sustainable human settlement planning and management in all countries.
11.3 - Till 2030 verka för en inkluderande och hållbar urbanisering samt förbättra kapaciteten för deltagandebaserad, integrerad och hållbar planering och förvaltning av bosättningar i alla länder.

13.b - Främja mekanismer för att höja förmågan till effektiv klimatrelaterad planering och förvaltning i de minst utvecklade länderna, med särskilt fokus på kvinnor, ungdomar samt lokala och marginaliserade samhällen.

13.b - Promote mechanisms for raising capacity for effective climate change-related planning and management in least developed countries and small island developing States, including focusing on women, youth and local and marginalized communities.

17.19 - By 2030, build on existing initiatives to develop measurements of progress on sustainable development that complement gross domestic product, and support statistical capacity-building in developing countries

17.19 - By 2030, build on existing initiatives to develop measurements of progress on sustainable development that complement gross domestic product, and support statistical capacity-building in developing countries.

2.2 - By 2030, end all forms of malnutrition, including achieving, by 2025, the internationally agreed targets on stunting and wasting in children under 5 years of age, and address the nutritional needs of adolescent girls, pregnant and lactating women and older persons.

2.2 - Senast 2030 avskaffa alla former av undernäring, bland annat genom att senast 2025 nå de internationellt överenskomna målen i fråga om tillväxthämning och undervikt bland barn under fem år, samt tillgodose tonårsflickors, gravida och ammande kvinnors samt äldre personers näringsbehov.

3.2 - By 2030, end preventable deaths of newborns and children under 5 years of age, with all countries aiming to reduce neonatal mortality to at least as low as 12 per 1,000 live births and under-5 mortality to at least as low as 25 per 1,000 live births.

3.2 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att inga spädbarn eller barn under fem år dör av orsaker som hade kunnat förebyggas. Alla länder bör sträva efter att minska den neonatala dödligheten till högst tolv dödsfall per 1 000 levande födda och dödligheten bland barn under fem år till högst 25 dödsfall per 1 000 levande födda.
4.6 - By 2030, ensure that all youth and a substantial proportion of adults, both men and women, achieve literacy and numeracy.
4.6 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla ungdomar och en väsentlig andel av alla vuxna – både män och kvinnor – lär sig läsa, skriva och räkna.
5.3 - Avskaffa alla skadliga sedvänjor, såsom barnäktenskap, tidiga äktenskap och tvångsäktenskap samt kvinnlig könsstympning.
5.3 - Eliminate all harmful practices, such as child, early and forced marriage and female genital mutilation.

6.2 - By 2030, achieve access to adequate and equitable sanitation and hygiene for all and end open defecation, paying special attention to the needs of women and girls and those in vulnerable situations.

6.2 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla har tillgång till fullgod och rättvis sanitet och hygien och att ingen behöver uträtta sina behov utomhus. Särskild uppmärksamhet bör ägnas åt behoven hos kvinnor och flickor samt människor i utsatta situationer.
