description.narrative: This information has been taken from conclusion on performance September 2020. The year 2019/20 marks the fifth and final year of implementation of the 2015-2020 strategic plan. The focus in the final year has been to ensure that all targets in the strategy were achieved. The approved PWB 2019/2020 focused on activities that provided outcomes that include: * Policy outreach through policy briefs and thesis dissemination. * Regional policy forums to engage and inform policy makers. * Resource mobilization across funders to close the financing gap in 2019/2020. * Continuing to enlarge the African stakeholdership through the AERC African Central Banks' Forum. * Private sector mutually beneficial engagement. * Developing the strategic directions for 2020-2025 to provide a seamless transition from the current planning cycle to the next; and, * Visibility of AERC through enhanced website management and roll-out of the communication strategy. Challenges remaining: The final year of the strategy had less resources, therefore, 2019/20 started with a financing gap. Even though this was covered, the Training program remains the one with reduced activity level and thus inflating the management cost ratios. The changing environment where most funders prefer short-term, earmarked funding is a recurring problem and challenge that will be even more significant in the future. Objective 1: Enhanced capacity building for economic policy research and graduate training in sub-Saharan Africa Two plenary sessions were held during the year. The first one, in June, was on the theme: "Growing with Debt in African Economies: Options, Challenges and Pitfalls". The second plenary session was on the theme: "Business Environment, Competitiveness and Economic Growth in Africa". The session was held in December in Nairobi in honour of Prof. Shantayanan Devarajan, following his retirement from the World Bank. At the two plenary sessions AERC as usually arranged policy roundtables and at both occasions the policy roundtables were "Ladies Policy Roundtable" with prominent female doctors and professors. The biannual research workshops took place at the same time as the plenary sessions. In total 48 doctoral students presented their work at the two workshops. The number of students graduates from CMAP and CMAAE are above the targets. The number of graduates from CPP is below the target, which can be explained by resource constraints to the training programmes. A number of activities took place within the Bridge programme. One of most important to mention is that 10 proposals were awarded development grants of US$3000 each for further development and analysis. So far, 8 (7 men and 1 female) out of 26 PhD bridge programme alumni have been awarded CPP scholarships. All six outcome indicators for the outcome "Enhanced participation of under-represented countries, groups and institutions, including post-conflict and fragile states in economic policy", show results above the set targets. Viewed in this light the conclusion is that the bridge-programme has been very successful. To improve and assure the quality at the training programmes examination of the courses is under the responsibility of the Academic Advisory Board, which held its meeting in May 2019, for approval of examination results. To support departments at the universities AERC awarded annual operating and institutional grants to 11 CMAP collaborating universities, 8 CPP degree-awarding universities and 8 CMAAE accredited universities. The achieved results (targets in brackets) for graduation of CMAP-universities was 4 (7) category-C, 7 (9) category-B and 15 (11) category-A. It means that the target was only met when it comes to accepting new universities into the AERC-network. One university was upgraded to an accredited university in the CMAAE programme, which was also the target. Objective 2: Build and strengthen national, regional and global linkages to generate high quality economic policy research and graduate training. During the reporting year AERC has successfully progressed with five collaborative research projects: * Healthcare Financing in Africa, is in the final stage and a final review workshop took place in October 2019 in Accra, Ghana. * Rethinking Trade and Regional Integration, is in the final stage and a final review workshop was held in October 2019, in Lusaka, Zambia. Two journals, The World Economy and Journal of African Trade, were identified for possible publication of articles. * Impact of Agricultural and Food Policies on Nutrition Outcomes in Africa - a mid-review and final review workshops were held in April 2019 and October 2019 and 15 research teams presented their work-in-progress and final reports. * Rethinking Relationships Between Growth, Poverty, Inequality and Redistribution in Africa, an inception workshop was held back to back with the June 2019 Biannual research workshop. Work-in-progress reports were discussed and commented on by Prof. Erik Thorbecke at a mid-review workshop. Of the 13 papers, 5 have been selected for presentation at the World Congress of the International Economic Association, IEA, in July 2020 in Indonesia. * Climate Change and Economic Development in Africa, 11 framework papers were commissioned at an inception workshop held back-to-back with the December 2019 Biannual research workshop. Prof. John Asafu-Adjaye was appointed as project coordinator and Prof. Théophile T. Azomahou was appointed as Resource Person. During the reporting year AERC became a member of T20 Think Tanks - a selected group of think tanks associated with the G20 platform. The T20 Think Tanks is a technical arm of G20 and work with research for policy making. AERC contributed to two policy briefs: "Industrial development and ICT in Africa" and Fiscal and Debt Sustainability in Africa". Objective 3: Engage the private sector in mutually beneficial research and training activities to enhance Innovation and to deepen and broaden AERC cpapcity building Two results areas were identified under this objective. The first one was to engage the private sector in AERC Plenary Conferences. At the June 2019 Biannual workshop six new research papers, relevant to the private sector, were presented. The number of actors from private sectors who have participated in AERC activities are above the set target while the set target for number of actors participating in dissemination activities were below the set target. Objective 4: Enhance AERC Visibility, Outreach as well as Policy Engagement to maximize the uptake of AERC Products in Policy AERC has achieved some interesting results under objective 4, during the fiscal year. A Communication Agency of Record was procured to help AERC modernise it's communication strategy and strategic around its visibility of its brand. Several activities in relation to that has taken place and will continue in the new strategic plan period. Publications from AERC has been made available from Columbia University, which has agreed to include publications and policy briefs within their library portal, which reaches 450 universities and institutions worldwide. AERC publications link with Research Papers in Economics (REPEC) has been restored after the url migration from Access Kenya to BlueHost. Specific publications that can be worth mentioning from the year are: A report book on Fragility of Growth in African Economies was published and distributed. A book-length volume on Fragility of Growth in African Economies was published in in February 2020. One Regional Policy Forum for the Central Africa Region was held in Kigali, Rwanda in December 2019. The title of the Policy Forum was "Gender and Resource Management for Economic Development". The aim with the Regional Policy Forums is to address the needs of the middle-level policy makers who have previously not been reached by the Senior Policy Seminars, bridging the gap between Senior Policy Seminars and national policy workshops. Objective 5: Maximise mutual benefits through diversified resources base and stakeholder-ship for sustainability AERC has been implementing a resource mobilization strategy with positive outcomes. For example the efforts to intensify existing partnerships resulted in six signed grant agreements with DFID, African Union Development Agency, ZEF (a German research institute), IDRC, Gates Foundation, GIZ. One of the key activities during the reporting year is the drafting and adoption of the strategic plan for 2020-2025. A mid-term evaluation report was conducted by Prof. Frances Stewart of oxford University and Prof. Ernest Aryeetey of the African Research Universities Alliance, Ghana. Based on lessons learnt, recommendations, and numerous consultations with the Board and other stakeholders, the strategic plan 2020-2025 has adopted a new approach focusing on outcomes and impact measurements. Improved HR capacity has also been achieved due to successful recruitment of a new Director of Research and a new Chief Finance Officer.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

title.narrative: Tillgång till rättvisa för kvinnor i Asien UN Women, ICJ och OHCHR i samverkan
UN Women, ICJ & OHCHR Access to Justice for women in Asia

description.narrative:
Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 UN Women, Internationella Juristkommissionen (ICJ) och FN:s högkommissaries kontor för mänskliga rättigheter (OHCHR) har ansökt om SEK 79 500 000 i stöd från Sida för att genomföra ett gemensamt regionalt projekt i Asien och Oceanien under benämningen: ”Enhancing Access to Justice for Women in Asia and the Pacific: Bridging the gap between formal and informal system through womens empowerment” (fritt översatt: Förbättra tillgång till rättvisa för kvinnor i Asien och Oceanien: Överbrygga gapet mellan formella och informella rättssystem genom att stärka kvinnors ställning”) under perioden 2018-2022.
Insatsen syftar till att stärka kvinnors tillgång till rättvisa och överkomma hinder i form av diskriminerande normer och lagar, kunskapsbrist och sociala mönster hos bl.a. rättsvårdande myndigheter, institutioner och domstolar. Projektet syftar till att stärka kvinnors ställning och kapacitet i kontakterna med rättvårdande institutioner. Projektet kommer att fokusera på Indonesien, Filippinerna, Nepal, Sri Lanka, Östtimor och länder i Oceanien.
Insatsen har tre huvudsakliga komponenter:
1. Att verka för att nationell lagstiftning och domstolsutslag överensstämmer med de internationella normer som definieras i bl. a FN:s kvinnokonvention (CEDAW). Projektet kommer sammanställa en jämförelse av nationella lagars med internationella normer och standarder och identifiera gap som behöver åtgärdas.
2. Att bidra till att stärka kunskapen och kapaciteten inom rättsvårdande institutioner om jämställhet och kvinnors rättigheter och bidra till att avskaffandet av könsbaserad diskriminering och sociala stereotyper som drabbar kvinnor negativt inom såväl formell som informell rättssektor.
3. Att stärka kvinnliga gräsrotsorganisationer så att de blir bättre rustade för att dokumentera, övervaka, samordna samverkan mellan formella och informella rättssystem i trygga former. Projektet ska genomföras av tre delatagande organisationerna i nära samarbete med lokala, nationella och regionala aktörer (domare, åklagare, polis, advokater, parlamentariker, lokala myndigheter, kvinnoorganisationer samt nationella MR-kommissioner).
Fördelningen av den totala budgeten per organisation: UN Women: 47 %, ICJ: 46.8% OHCHR: 6.3 %. UN Women tar ut en administrativ kostnad på 8 % av projekts totala budget. Hälften av pengarna som går till UN Women kommer att vidareförmedlas som stöd till civilsamhällesorganisationer under hela 5-årsperioden.
Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 regional support to civil society organisations with the purpose to support rule of law, a cooperation between ICJ, OHCHR and UNWOMEN

The project "Enhancing Access to Justice for Women in Asia and the Pacific. Bridging the gap between formal and informal systems through women's empowerment" is a five-year program with an overarching goal to enhance access to justice for women in both formal and informal justice systems. The project is built on previous experiences The objective of the project is to build on previous global and regional work on Access to Justice for women e.g. The work and experience made by ICJ under the European funded ASEAN program. During the project ICJ consolidated network of lawyers working on Human rights cases in the region and established relationships with courts across the region. ICJ initiated regional judicial dialogues with senior judges in South East Asia. One important outcome was the development and adoption, in 2016, of the Bangkok General Guidance on Applying a Gender Perspective for judges. ICJ has also experiences from intervening in emblematic cases regarding the interpretation of and application of laws that expressively discriminate against women and LGBT people. The project also builds on the experiences made in the regional project UN Women CEDAW South Est Asia regional program 2011-2016 focusing on knowledge generation and exchange, stock taking and priority setting for advancing the implementation of CEDAW in the region. The overall goal was reduced discrimination against women in South-East Asia and enhanced South-East Asia regional processes that facilitate CEDAW implementation. In addition, the UN Office of the High Commissioner for human rights (OHCHR) regional office has the global mandate for human rights and supports justice processes that are consistent with international law and good practices and brings a comparative advantage in supporting judicial reform efforts to protect human rights. OHCHR has expertise and experiences to address issues related to women’s access to justice. The UN Women project included important research in several countries with plural legal systems and concluded that there are substantial gaps in women's access to justice in countries with plural legal systems. In addition, negative gender stereotyping and discriminatory attitudes among judges, prosecutors and police were pervasive. Discriminatory legislation is another serious obstacle for Women's access to justice. The project has a geographical focus on 6 countries in Asia and Pacific: Indonesia, Philippines and Timor Leste, Nepal, Sri Lanka and Pacific Island Countries. Against this background the A2J project has he project has three specific outputs: 1.) Advocacy is conducted to promote the adoption of domestic laws and court decisions in the target countries consistent with international human rights law and standards, including CEDAW 2.) Gender discriminatory attitudes and stereotyped behaviours towards women are acknowledged and addressed by formal and informal justice providers in the target countries. 3.) Grassroots women's organizations and community-based women's organizations are empowered and well positioned to document, monitor, liase and facilitate interaction with formal and informal justice providers. The programme results are based on the theory of change that if there is: i. A legal enabling environment for women to access gender-responsive justice is created by advocating for laws and court decisions that are consistent with international human rights law and standards, including the CEDAW; ii. Plural justice systems are gender-responsive because gaps between formal and informal settings are bridged through increased understanding and awareness of justice system providers of women’s rights; iii. Grassroots women’s organizations and community-based women’s organizations are empowered and well positioned to document and facilitate interactions between and with formal and informal justice providers, and their resilience is enhanced to build a just and sustainable future; Then, women’s access to justice will be enhanced in the Asia Pacific region.

participating-org.narrative: UNWOMEN/United Nations Entity for Gender Equality and the Empowerment of Women
United Nations Entity for Gender Equality and the Empowerment of Women

tag.narrative: 16.3 - Främja rättssäkerheten på nationell och internationell nivå samt säkerställa lika tillgång till rättvisa för alla.
16.3 - Promote the rule of law at the national and international levels and ensure equal access to justice for all.
5.1 - Avskaffa alla former av diskriminering av alla kvinnor och flickor överallt
5.1 - End all forms of discrimination against all women and girls everywhere.

Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Adaptation

description.narrative: During this reporting period (the period from January 2019 to December 2019), the project ‘“Enhancing Access to Justice for Women in Asia and the Pacific; Bridging the gap between formal and informal systems through women’s empowerment in Asia and the Pacific” carried out activities as planned. It was able to reach different target groups in Asia and the Pacific region with a focus on Indonesia, Nepal, the Philippines, Timor-Leste, Sri Lanka, Malaysia and the Pacific. At the community-level, 30 grass-roots organizations strengthened their knowledge on women’s access to justice, and over 1,600 community members benefitted from the 40 community awareness sessions on gender discriminatory norms. At the national level, the programme reached over 500 women lawyers to increase their knowledge and skills. To advance women’s rights at the regional level, the programme conducted a Regional Judicial Dialogue on the Elimination on Discrimination against Women and hosted a consultation in support of the Special Rapporteur’s work on the right to freedom of religion or belief. Regarding the intervention on the environment perspective, there was the establishment of the Pacific Human Rights Defenders Network to strengthen the voices of women to tackle climate change. In addition, the programme partners used their internationally recognized mandates to shed light on women’s rights issues in Asia, utilizing the United Nations Human Rights Council sessions. In sum, through the partnership between UN Women, ICJ, and OHCHR, the programme was able to reach different target groups by implementing bottom-up activities such as community dialogues on women’s rights as well as regional dialogues with judges and members of United Nations Special Procedures. Examples of results Output 1. Adoption of domestic laws and court decisions in the target countries consistent with international human rights law and standards, including the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women, is promoted. In Indonesia, ICJ OHCHR and UN Women worked with non-governmental organizations, government bodies, and United Nations agencies on the proposed amendment of the draft Criminal Code that contains explicit discriminatory sections against women. Finally the Indonesian legislature did not pass the Penal Code amendments in 2019, which provides the programme with the opportunity to continue government dialogues, support to human rights groups, and to mobilize communities to advocate for CEDAW-compliant legislative change. In Nepal, the Nepal Bar Association conducted its 28th National Conference of Women Lawyers, which was attended by over 500 female legal professionals and resulted in the adoption of the 21-Point Dharan Declaration which focused on addressing existing barriers to the effective implementation and formulation of gender-responsive laws and policies. In the Philippines, ICJ has been working closely with the Integrated Bar of the Philippines (IBP) to train lawyers to provide legal services to women. Consequently, IBP established a Gender and Development (GAD) Committee, which has the mandate of ensuring gender equality in the legal profession and eliminating gender discriminatory practices among lawyers. The Supreme Court of the Philippines approved the request of IBP to instate GAD as one of the standing and permanent committees of the Bar Association. Output 2: Gender discriminatory attitudes and behaviours towards women by formal and informal justice providers are acknowledged and addressed by formal and informal justice providers in the target countries. In collaboration with the Malaysian Judicial Academy and the Federal Court of Malaysia, ICJ co-organized a Regional Judicial Dialogue on the Elimination of Discrimination against Women. Feedback from participants indicated that the content and discussions of the judicial dialogue significantly increased their knowledge of relevant international human rights law and standards related to the elimination of discrimination against women, including CEDAW and the Bangkok General Guidance. The majority of the participants stated they will use the knowledge, information, and tools presented at the judicial dialogue in their work as judges at the domestic level. The regional consultation with the Special Rapporteur’s work on the right to freedom of religion or belief in the context of non-discrimination as the dialogue platform for human rights defenders, formal justice providers from across Asia, including Bangladesh, Brunei, India, Indonesia, Malaysia, Myanmar, Pakistan, Philippines, and Thailand. The objectives of the consultation were to provide a forum for participants, particularly WHRDs and HRDs for sexual orientation, gender identity and expression, and sex characteristics (SOGIESC), and faith-based actors, to share their perspectives on laws, practices, and anti-rights strategies that discriminate against individuals in Asia based on SOGIESC. Based on this dialogue, the report to the United Nations Human Rights Council was developed on “Countering the false dichotomy between the right to freedom of religion or belief and the right to non-discrimination: Challenges on the ground and the need for human rights literacy”. Output 3. Grass-roots women’s organizations and community-based women’s organizations are empowered and well-positioned to document, monitor, liaise, and facilitate interactions with formal and informal justice providers, and their resilience is enhanced to build a just and sustainable future. In Nepal, the programme chose to work with 10 municipalities on a community-based justice approach. UN Women interventions, carried out by its national and local CSO partners, enhanced the capacity of community-based justice mechanisms (formal and informal) and increased women’s confidence and legal literacy. Women’s grass-roots organizations and WHRDs were supported and communities were involved for protection and social change. In Timor-Leste, UN Women in partnership with Timor-Leste's National Directorate for Community Conflict Prevention (DNPCC) developed the gender-responsive mediation guidelines as well as a gender-responsive case management system. OHCHR co-organized a workshop for indigenous youth HRDs in Bangkok. A safe space to discuss human rights, women’s rights, and climate justice issues was provided to indigenous youth HRDs. Considering the severe impact of climate change on small Pacific Islands States, OHCHR Pacific Office supports WHRDs, to increase their capacity to monitor the implementation of human rights, liaise with key stakeholders, follow up on human rights treaty body recommendations, and use human rights mechanisms. It strengthens women’s understanding of how to engage with government, national human rights institutions, and justice representatives on human rights issues, including in the context of climate change and business. To this end, OHCHR supported the creation of the Pacific Human Rights Defenders Network, which was launched in July 2019. Though the key activities were proactively implemented through local, national, and regional approach, it is apparent that more results oriented, analytical and qualitative reporting is still needed. During this reporting year, some activities have just been started up. This explains the report is activity-based rather than result-oriented. In the upcoming reporting, the results/outcomes of these initiatives will be followed up and reported. Covid19 consequences to programming In the first six months of 2020, the COVID-19 pandemic has affected almost all countries given the health, economic and social challenges. In addition, COVID-19 has deepened social injustice and highlighted the dire consequences of poor leadership and a weak rule of law. For WA2J, programme activities that were scheduled for 2020 were revisited and amended to fit the context. Women grassroots organizations received financial and technical support to continue their work, provide protection and support to women in the communities. The programme partners conducted a number of webinars with legal service providers, conducted research on the impact of COVID on women’s access to justice and partnered with local NGOs to conduct virtual scoping missions. Activities in some countries with lower COVID impact, e.g. Timor-Leste and Fiji, were continued. Funds that were not utilized for travel were partially used to subscribe to online platforms and to upscale technical know-how on how to engage with our stakeholders online.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

COVID-19 UN Women, ICJ & OHCHR Access to Justice for women in Asia

In addition, COVID-19 has deepened social injustice and highlighted the dire consequences of poor leadership and a weak rule of law. For WA2J, programme activities that were scheduled for 2020 were revisited and amended to fit the context. Women grassroots organizations received financial and technical support to continue their work, provide protection and support to women in the communities. The programme partners conducted a number of webinars with legal service providers, conducted research on the impact of COVID on women’s access to justice and partnered with local NGOs to conduct virtual scoping missions. Activities in some countries with lower COVID impact, e.g. Timor-Leste and Fiji, were continued. Funds that were not utilized for travel were partially used to subscribe to online platforms and to upscale technical know-how on how to engage with our stakeholders online.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

description.narrative: Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 CEFs huvudsakliga mål är att finansiera projekt inom "ren Energi", dvs. förnybart, energieff, och tillgång till energi. Fonden finansierar även pilotprojekt, utveckling av policy, finansieringsmetoder etc. för att stimulere ren energi.

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 Clean Energy Fund is part of ADB Clean Energy Financing Partnership Facility. Main objective to finance projects in clean energy, major demonstration projects, policy development and mode of fundings.

description.narrative: The CEFPF’s performance measure against the target outcome at the completion of all projects in its portfolio. To date, the combined support of the CEFPF and Climate Change Fund Clean Energy Component (CCF-CE) have surpassed the (two) outcome level targets for CO2 emission reduction (27.1 million tons of CO2 emission reduction/year attained vs. target of 20.0 million of CO2 emission reduction/year) and energy savings (18.7 terra-watt hour-equivalent/year of energy savings attained vs. target of 18.0 TWh-eq/year). The installed renewable energy capacity reached 2,329.8 mega-watt (MW) which is 67% achievement rate of the 3,500 MW target. Meanwhile, the renewable energy generation reached 7.4 TWh/year which is 74% achievement rate of the 10 TWh/year target. In terms of outputs level indicators, 12 out of the 16 indicators are progressing well and have achieved at least 75% of the target. There are 4 output indicators that require significant work which include households provided with access to energy in participating developing member countries (DMCs) supported, households connected to modern fuels and/or efficient devices for heating, households connected to modern fuels and/or efficient devices for cooking, and carbon capture and storage demonstration projects. Gender aspects is related to the output - Benefits from access to energy delivered. To date, CEFPF has supported 36 projects with access to energy components that will benefit 392,887 households provided with energy access. This number falls short of the target 700,000 household, which illustrates the difficulty encountered by the CEFPF in attracting access to energy projects. The CEFPF will continue the multi-sector approach including sectors such as transport, agriculture, water and education sectors that are likely to integrate more clean renewable energy solutions into project design and development. In energy sector, the ADB is addressing the impact of CVOID-19 through projects. For example, the outbreak of the Coronavirus disease has raised concerns on the transmission of viruses through centralized air conditioning (CAC) systems. In many ADB's Developing Member Countries (DMCs), the risk of transmission in CAC systems is higher because of inadequate hygiene standards. Toward this, the CEFPF co-financed a Knowledge and Support Technical Assistance (KSTA) to support DMCs mitigate the risks of virus transmission and ensure safe working conditions in public buildings by deploying efficient, clean, and smart CAC systems. It is envisioned that pilot systems will demonstrate the effectively of the technology and be taken up by the DMCs to mitigate the risk of COVID-19 and other transmittable diseases.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Det Europieska Skogsinstitutet (European Forest Institute, EFI) har ansökt om stöd att genomföra EU FLEGT Action Plan i Asien (FLEGT Asia II) genom EU FLEGT Facility som stödjer genomförandet av det övergripande programmet EU FLEGT Action Plan som är aktivt i Latinamerika, Afrika och Asien. FLEGT står för Forest Law Enforcement Governance and Trade. FLEGT bekämpar illegalt skogsbruk och stödjer förbättrad skogsförvaltning. Det svenska bidraget stödjer det övergripande målet med EU FLEGT Asia men kommer att fokusera på två områden. 1. Att stärka det regionala samarbetet inom FLEGT i Asien. 2. Definiera policies och mekanismer, inkl. pilotprojekt, för stöd till små, mellan- och medelstora företag (SME´s) i att uppfylla de strängare marknadskraven för export av timmer och trävaror till EU-länder som FLEGT med tillhörande regler innebär.
Det totala budgeten för FLEGT Asia är (2013-2019) är 11,9 miljoner Euro. Öronmärkt finansiering till FLEGT Asia kommer från: Europeiska Kommissionen (EC) 4,8 miljoner Euro, Holland 1 miljon Euro, Sverige 4 miljoner Euro. Underskott i finansieringen är f.n. 2,1 miljoner Euro. EFI uppger att Holland planerar att förlänga och öka sitt stöd och att Finland har uttryckt intresse. Därutöver får FLEGT Asia del av icke öronmärkta pengar från EU FLEGT Facility om Styrkommittéen så beslutar, vilket redan sker.
En portföljanalys har genomförts i enlighet med Sidas (EKOADM:s) tolkning av regleringsbrevets villkor om att undvika att teckna större och/eller längre avtal mot slutet av en strategiperiod eftersom det är EKOADM på Sida som ansvarar för hur regleringsbrevet ska tolkas. Nuvarande strategi löper ut under 2015. Målet att minst 50 respektive 75 procent av nuvarande årsvolym (200 MSEK) skall vara ointecknat ett respektive två år efter det att strategin löper ut, uppfylls. Den föreslagna insatsen har sista utbetalningsår 2018 och avtalsslut under 2019, vilket överensstämmer med EKOADM:s tolkning av villkoret gällande hur långt in i framtiden en utbetalning kan genomföras och avtal sträcka sig efter strategiperiodens slut. (ref till Sida beslut för stöd till Mangroves For the Future, MFF, Phase 3, Sida beslutsnummer 2014-002025).

Overall objective: To contribute to poverty eradication and sustainable forest management in Asia. Outcome objectives: 1. Increased institutional dialogue on timber legality and trade in different regional forums and platforms. 2. Synergies among regional/ASEAN policies and FLEGT Action Plan to strengthen political support for eliminating illegal timber trade and promoting legal consumption in regional trade are identified. 3. Support mechanisms enabling SMEs to comply with changing market requirements are defined and piloted.

description.narrative: At the EU Facility level, according to mid-term progress report January-June 2020, key highlight of delivery results are, for example: - One formal Voluntary Partnership Agreement (VPA) negotiation took place between the EU and Côte d'Ivoire while the planned negotiation with Laos and Thailand were postponed. In spite of the challenges by the corona crisis, in many countries, the commitment to the VPA process remained strong. - Progress was made at the technical level, for example: the revision at the thematic group on Timber Legality Assurance Systems (TLAS) and the legality definition in Cameroon and Thailand; the setting up a new thematic group on TLAS and the legality definition in Côte d'Ivoire; and regulatory revisions in Indonesia. - A lot of desk-based work have been done, e.g. the Facility updated all its FLEGT country webpages on its website, captured evidence in areas of governance applicable to FLEGT or VPA processes in partner countries, documented the impact of trainings of Micro, Small and Medium Enterprises (MSMEs) in the Mekong region and published impact stories related the VPA processes in Ghana and Thailand. For Sida Special Work on Regional Asia and MSMEs, EFI made progress in the documentation and dissemination of lessons learned of the MSMEs work. EFI published the paper Small and Micro-sized entities in the Mekong region’s forest sector and raised awareness about the MSME work in regional fora such as the Asia Pacific Forestry Week, the 7th TLAS Workshop in late 2019 in Indonesia and in APEC Experts Group on Illegal Logging and Associated Trade meeting in Malaysia in early 2020. Gender equality was strengthened through a gender workshop organized by WOCAN under the Regional Asia gender helpdesk framework. EFI informed that the workshop was successful and received positive feedback from their participants. The training took a hands-on approach and was a good balance of theoretical introductions to key concepts in gender, tools for gender analysis, and group work to practice the tools. One good lesson learned is that prior to the training, EFI had three meetings with the WOCAN to underline the objectives of the training, share information about participants, introduce the SmE work and FLEGT. EFI informed that the regional work supported by Sida until the end of 2020 will become part of the new FLEGT Asia program and contribute to the dialogue between the EU and ASEAN+3. This means that financial resource for Sida special work can be more focused on the MSME activities and linking to regional level while the Regional Asia work will still be implementing from the EU resources.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

New/additional funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 DKT International (US-based non-for-profit) have submitted an application for a regional programme to contribute to improved sexual and reproductive health and rights in six countries in the region (Tanzania, Ethiopia, Kenya, Uganda, DRC, Mozambique). Focus is on decreasing the number of unwanted pregnancies and the availability to safe abortion. By increasing peoples access to a wide range of contraceptives, like IUD and implants, one contributes to their opportunities to decide over their own bodies and fertility. The programme is also specifically focused on young people through efforts to reduce teenage pregnancies and this is intended to help reduce the maternal mortality rates. The programme will also complement the programmes implemented through existing health systems and the public sector which often suffers from lack of resources. This complementing programme with the private sector is intended to contribute to reduced poverty and in the end support economic development. The six countries have demographical similarities when it comes to the large number of Young people, high maternal mortality rates and a huge unmet need for information and health services related to sexual and reproductive health and rights related to access to and the use of modern contraceptives (Contraceptive Prevalence Rates - CPR).This regional programme is planned to complement programmes at bilateral in those countries where Sida is working on SRHR. There are also clear Connections to Sidas global programme support to strategic partners such as IPAS and IPPF who are also working on SRHR, contraceptives and abortion. Synergies will be explored throughout the programme and there is also a firm interest from DKT International to look at potential connections and collaborations at bilateral level as well as with Sidas partners at global level,of which many are already established collaborating partners with DKT International. DKT International are well established as one of the worlds' main organisations with expertise in Contraceptive Social Marketing (CSM). In Ethiopia DKT is running the largest programme in the country on contraceptives and safe abortion since 1990 and it also represents the third largest CSM programme in the World. The proposed programme is over 4 years (2016-2020) and has a budget of a total 80 million SEK and Sida is the first and so far only donor to this regional programme. This is based on the fact that there are very few regional SRHR-focused donors in the region and ever fewer that are focusing on access to safe and legal abortions. There is a possibility that other donors who has expressed an interest for this programme will contribute with funding later on. A potential support from Sida is expected to generate 28 million Couple Years Protection (CYP), which is a method used to estimate the protection against a pregnancy during one year by different contraceptive methods. Sidas support will be used for procurement of contraceptives, marketing and targeted youth activities. It will also be used to increase collaboration with the private health sector (clinics and pharmacies) to increase access to safe abortions wherever legal. The country offices are responsible for implementation and the head office in Washington DC bears the financial responsibility. The programme will mainly focus on large volumes of procured contraceptives and abortion-related medicines and Equipment as well as distribution of these through strategic marketing. It also finances training and competence-building for health staff, both within the public and the private sector with focus on SRHR and counseling. Special youth activities will also be implemented with the purpose to reduce the number of unwanted pregnancies and increase the knowledge about SRHR generally.

Nya medel/medeltillägg för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 DKT International (US-baserad non-profit organisation) har inkommit med en ansökan för ett regionalt program för att långsiktigt bidra till förbättrad sexuell och reproduktiv hälsa och rättigheter i sex länder i regionen (Tanzania, Etiopien, Kenya, Uganda, Demokratiska Republiken Kongo, Mozambique). Fokus ligger på att minska antalet oönskade graviditeter och osäkra aborter genom ökad tillgång till preventivmedel och erbjudandet av säker abort. Genom att öka människors tillgång till ett utbud av preventivmedel inkl. fokus på långtidsverkande preventivmedel, såsom tex. spiral och p-stav, bidrar man till deras möjlighet att själva bestämma över sin fertilitet. Insatsen avser också att särskilt fokusera på ungdomar genom att bidra till ett minskat antal tonårsgraviditeter och detta avses bidra till minskade mödradödlighetssiffror. Insatsen bidrar även till att komplettera de insatser som genomförs genom befintliga hälsosystem och den offentliga sektorn som ofta lider av bristande resurser. Denna komplementerande insats inom privata sektorn avses bidra till minskad fattigdom och i slutändan gynna ekonomisk utveckling.
De sex länderna har demografiskt stora likheter i vad det gäller ett stort antal unga människor, höga mödradödlighetssiffror och kraftigt undersatta behov av information och vård när det gäller sexuell och reproduktiv hälsa och rättigheter. Tillgången till och användingen av moderna preventivmedel (Contraceptive Prevalence Rates - CPR) är tex. i Uganda endast 8%. I Etiopien, som är det andra mest befolkningstäta landet i Afrika med ca 100 miljoner människor, utgör mer än 66% unga under 25 år. I Tanzania är över 50% under 18 år och trenden ser liknande ut i de övriga länderna. Det finns därmed ett stort utrymme för att bredda marknaden i regionen vad gäller tillgången till preventivmedel och speciellt bland unga, givet de demografiska likheterna. Det finns även stor potential att bygga på redan tagna initiativ och pågående program som DKT implementerar i dessa sex länder.
Detta regionala program avser komplettera bilaterala insatser inom SRHR-området i de länder där Sida arbetar inom hälsa. Inledande dialog har först med ambassaderna i Kinshasa, Maputo och Dar es Salaam. Vidare konsultationer kommer att genomföras med dessa samt med ambassaderna i Kampala och Addis Abeba. Det finns också tydliga kopplingar till Sidas globala stöd till strategiskt viktiga organisationer som tex. International Pregnancy Advisory Services (IPAS) och International Planned Parenthood Federation (IPPF) som också arbetar med SRHR, preventivmedel och abort. Synergier kommer att utvecklas vidare under programmets gång och det finns också ett stort intresse från DKT International att närmare utforska kopplingar och samarbeten på bilateral nivå, såväl som med Sidas partners på global nivå, varav flertalet redan är etablerade samarbetspartners med DKT International.
DKT International är väl etablerade som en av världens främsta organisationer med expertis inom Contraceptive Social Marketing (CSM). I Etiopien bedriver DKT International det största programmet i landet inom preventivmedel och säker abort sedan 1990 och det utgör även det tredje största programmet inom CSM i världen. Den föreslagna insatsen löper över 4 år (2016-2020) och omfattar totalt 80 miljoner kronor och Sida är den första och än så länge enda finansiären till detta regionala program. Detta grundar sig i att det för närvarande finns mycket få regionala SRHR-inriktade givare i regionen och ännu färre som fokuserar på tillgång till säker abort. Det finns dock en möjlighet att andra givare som uttryckt intresse för programmet kommer att bidra med stöd framöver. Ett potentiellt stöd från Sida beräknas genererera 28 miljoner Couple Years Protection (CYP), vilket är en mätmetod för att uppskatta skyddet mot graviditet under ett år av olika typer av preventivmedel. Sidas stöd kommer att gå till upphandling av preventivmedel, marknadsföring och särskilda ungdomssatsningar. Det kommer också att gå till att utöka samarbeten med privata hälsosektorn (bl.a. kliniker och apotek) för att öka tillgången till säkra aborter där detta är lagligt.
Landkontoren har ansvar för implementering av verksamheten och huvudkontoret i Washington DC bär det finansiella ansvaret. Programmet finansierar i huvudsak inköp av stora volymer preventivmedel och abort-relaterade mediciner och utrustning samt distribuering av dessa genom strategisk marknadsföring. Det finansierar även utbildning och kompetenshöjande insatser för sjukvårdspersonal, både inom offentlig och privat sektor med fokus på SRHR och rådgivning. Särskilda ungdomssatsningar kommer också att genomföras med syftet att få ner antalet oönskade graviditeter samt öka kunskapen om SRHR generellt.

The programme by DKT International aims to reverse the high number of unwanted pregnancies and unsafe abortions by ensuring that a wide range of contraceptive methods are available, affordable and of high quality. The programme also intends to increase access to safe abortion services (where legal) including post-abortion care (PAC) counselling and SRHR information. By expanding the scale and scope of the procurement of contraceptives, to prevent regular stock-outs of commodities, more women and men will have a broader access to a wide range of contraceptive methods. In addition to focusing on supply of contraceptives and medical abortion products, strategic marketing and brand-building that caters to different segments of the population, creates demand. By reducing the barriers to accessing contraceptives and informing the general public of the value of using contraceptives, DKT operates from the assumption that many people will ultimately use their own funds to pay for the products and services they want as long as they are affordable and accessible. This has proven to be the fact in many countries around the world, where DKT is operating and even in low-income countries. The poorest of the poor and those who do not have the money to pay for contraceptives or health services are often targeted by other NGOs, UN, donors (for example with free condoms) and governments themselves. DKT does not claim to target this segment of the population as the prime objective of the programme. They do however also focus on the poor, underserved communities and high-risk groups and they engage with young people through different marketing strategies to reach those who are not able to pay and they also procure commodities which are distributed for free by other organisations. The intended outcome of this programme is to increase the contraceptive prevalence rates through increased number of Couple Years Protection (CYP) and reduced costs per CYP as well as ensuring safe abortion services are available wherever legal. Sida funds will result in increased sales and services and contribute to the drive for health impact with focus on reduced number of unwanted pregnancies and unsafe abortions with a general impact on peoples' SRHR.

tag.narrative: 3.7 - By 2030, ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health-care services, including for family planning, information and education, and the integration of reproductive health into national strategies and programmes.

3.7 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla har tillgång till sexuell och reproduktiv hälsovård, inklusive familjeplanering, information och utbildning, och att reproduktiv hälsa integreras i nationella strategier och program.

5.6 - Ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health and reproductive rights as agreed in accordance with the Programme of Action of the International Conference on Population and Development and the Beijing Platform for Action and the outcome documents of their review conferences.

5.6 - Säkerställa allmän tillgång till sexuell och reproduktiv hälsa och reproduktiva rättigheter i enlighet med överenskommelserna i handlingsprogrammet från den internationella konferensen om befolkning och utveckling, Pekingplattformen samt slutdokumenten från respektive översynskonferenser.

description.narrative:
Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 EAC-sekretariatet has ansökt om stöd för ett integrerat regionalt hälsoprogram under 2016-2020.
Programmets syfte är att, på policynivå, hantera svagheter inom medlemländernas hälsosystem. Om EACs medlemsländer gemensamt och effektivt harmoniserar standarder för SRHR-, mödra-, barn-och HIV/AIDS-hälsotjänster kommer detta att stärka det regional samarbetet inom hälsa. Vidare syftar interventionen till att stärka relevant forskning, innovationer, kunskapsspridning, ledarskap, styrning och ansvarsutkrävande inom regionen. EAC förväntar sig att det långsiktiga resultatet av ett fördjupat samarbete inom ovan nämnda områden kommer att vara att snabbare nå målen om att eliminera den mödra- och barnadödlighet som går att förhindra och att på sikt stoppa AIDS-epidemin.
Projektet har en budget på 45 miljoner kronor över 4,25 år och Sida är den enda givaren. Projektet är en del av EAC-sekretariatets mer övergripande hälsostrategi som omfattar även andra givare. Huvuddelen av projektets kostnader omfattas av löner för anställda vid EAC-sekretariatet samt kostnader för de processer som framtagande av EAC-gemensamma policydokument innebär (möteskostnader, resor m.m).

Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 The EAC secretariat has applied for support to the EAC-Sida integrated health program 2016-2020.
The purpose of the program is to, at a policy level, address weaknesses of member states' health systems. If the member states collectively and effectively harmonize standards for SRHR- maternal-, child and HIV/AIDS health services this will in turn strengthen regional cooperation in health. Furthermore, the program seeks to strengthen relevant research, innovation, knowledge management, leadership, governance and accountability within the region. The EAC expects that the long-term outcome of a deeper collaboration in the abovementioned areas will be that the goals of eliminating preventable maternal- and child mortality and eventually ending the AIDS-epidemic can be reached faster.
The project has a budget of 45 million SEK over 4.25 years and Sida is the sole donor. The project part of the EAC-secretariats more overarching health strategy which includes also other donors. The majority of costs are represented by salaries of project staff at the EAC-secretariat and costs related to development of EAC policies (e.g. workshops, travels, consultancy fees)

tag.narrative: 3.1 - By 2030, reduce the global maternal mortality ratio to less than 70 per 100,000 live births.
3.1 - Till 2030 minska mödradödligheten i världen till mindre än 70 dödsfall per 100 000 förlossningar med levande barn.

3.2 - By 2030, end preventable deaths of newborns and children under 5 years of age, with all countries aiming to reduce neonatal mortality to at least as low as 12 per 1,000 live births and under-5 mortality to at least as low as 25 per 1,000 live births.

3.2 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att inga spädbarn eller barn under fem år dör av orsaker som hade kunnat förebyggas. Alla länder bör sträva efter att minska den neonatala dödligheten till högst tolv dödsfall per 1 000 levande födda och dödligheten bland barn under fem år till högst 25 dödsfall per 1 000 levande födda.
3.3 - By 2030, end the epidemics of AIDS, tuberculosis, malaria and neglected tropical diseases and combat hepatitis, water-borne diseases and other communicable diseases.
3.3 - Senast 2030 utrota epidemierna av aids, tuberkulos, malaria och försummade tropiska sjukdomar samt bekämpa hepatit, vattenburna sjukdomar och andra smittsamma sjukdomar.

3.7 - By 2030, ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health-care services, including for family planning, information and education, and the integration of reproductive health into national strategies and programmes.

3.7 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla har tillgång till sexuell och reproduktiv hälsovård, inklusive familjeplanering, information och utbildning, och att reproduktiv hälsa integreras i nationella strategier och program.

3.8 - Achieve universal health coverage, including financial risk protection, access to quality essential health-care services and access to safe, effective, quality and affordable essential medicines and vaccines for all.

3.8 - Åstadkomma allmän hälso- och sjukvård för alla, som även skyddar mot ekonomisk risk, tillgång till grundläggande hälso- och sjukvård av god kvalitet liksom tillgång till säkra, effektiva och ekonomiskt överkomliga grundläggande läkemedel och vaccin av god kvalitet.

title.narrative: COVID-19 AECF 2017-22 Renewable Energy and Adaptation to Climate Technologies (REACT)
COVID-19 AECF 2017-22 Renewable Energy and Adaptation to Climate Technologies (REACT)

description.narrative:
New/additional funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 The contribution consists of support to a Challenge Fund; REACT (Renewable Energy, Adaptation and Climate Change Technology). REACT - sub-Saharan Africa, is administered by Afica Enterprise Challenge Fund Ltd (AECF), a non-profit company with AGRA (African Green Revolution) as the sole owner/member. AGRA is a "“non profit organization registered in Washington State as a public charity”. The contribution includes components in seven of Sweden's cooperation countries and the regional strategy for sub-Saharan Africa.
The objective of REACT is to stimulate small and medium-sized companies, to develop business models, services and products in renewable energy and energy efficiency that improve the lives of the poor. The idea is that companies supported by REACT are prepared to take risks, which they otherwise would not take. The ideas put forward by the companies, are identified through competitions in the respective countries. Applications are assessed on the basis of clear and transparent criteria and in three separate steps - this, to assure an independent and transparent process. REACT also supports capacity development of enterprises in a variety of areas, brokering service for successful companies to access capital for scaling up, learning and advocacy on national and regional issues (laws, rules, licensing, trade barriers etc.).
The decision on the intervention covers five years and amounts to 400 000 000 SEK.

Nya medel/medeltillägg för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Insatsen består av ett stöd till en Challenge Fund; REACT (Renewable Energy, Adaptation and Climate Technology). REACT administreras av Africa Enterprise Challenge Fund Ldt (AECF), med Alliance for a Green Revolution in Africa (AGRA) som enda ägare/medlem. AECF är ett icke-vinstdrivande företag och AGRA är en "non profit organization registered in Washington State as a public charity”. AECF är registrerat på Mauritus som bedömts som det afrikanska land som har den mest lämpliga företagslagstiftningen för att kunna bedriva AECF's verksamhet. För att få bedriva verksamhet utanför Mauritius finns bara alternativet "Global Business Licence" enligt gällande lagstiftning.
Insatsen omfattar sju av Sveriges samarbetsländer samt den regionala strategin för Afrika söder om Sahara.
Syftet med REACT är att stimulera små och medelstora företag, att utveckla affärsmodeller, service och produkter inom förnybar energi som förbättrar livet för fattiga. REACT bygger på att företagen med stöd från REACT är beredda att ta risker de annars inte skulle göra. Företagen identifieras via tävlingar i de respektive länderna, där ansökningar bedöms utifrån tydliga och transparenta kriterier. Urvalet görs i tre steg, och med hjälp av olika aktörer för varje steg. Detta för att säkerställa en oberoende och öppen process. I stödet ingår även insatser för kapacitetsutveckling av förtagen inom en rad olika områden, märklarservice för framgångsrika företag att få tillgång till kapital för att utöka sin verksamhet, lärande och påverkansarbete i nationella och regionala frågor (lagar, handelshinder etc.). Totalt ska cirka 324 000 hushåll få förbättrad tillgång till förnybar energi samtidigt som cirka 200 000 ton CO2 utsläpp undviks.
Insatsbeslutet är femårigt och uppgår totalt till 400 MSEK. Av beloppet avsätts 2 MSEK inom den regionala strategin för extern uppföljning och bedömning av resultat samt för att bidra till lärande mellan olika länder.

sector.narrative: Energy generation, renewable sources - multiple technologies

tag.narrative: 17.3 - Mobilisera additionella finansiella resurser till utvecklingsländerna från många olika källor.
17.3 - Mobilize additional financial resources for developing countries from multiple sources.
7.1 - By 2030, ensure universal access to affordable, reliable and modern energy services.
7.1 - Senast 2030 säkerställa allmän tillgång till ekonomiskt överkomliga, tillförlitliga och moderna energitjänster.
7.2 - By 2030, increase substantially the share of renewable energy in the global energy mix.
7.2 - Till 2030 väsentligen öka andelen förnybar energi i den globala energimixen.
7.3 - By 2030, double the global rate of improvement in energy efficiency.
7.3 - Till 2030 fördubbla den globala förbättringstakten vad gäller energieffektivitet.

7.a - By 2030, enhance international cooperation to facilitate access to clean energy research and technology, including renewable energy, energy efficiency and advanced and cleaner fossil-fuel technology, and promote investment in energy infrastructure and clean energy technology.

7.a - Till 2030 stärka det internationella samarbetet för att underlätta tillgång till forskning och teknik inom ren energi, inklusive förnybar energi, energieffektivitet samt avancerad och renare fossilbränslebaserad teknik, samt främja investeringar i energiinfrastruktur och ren energiteknik.

title.narrative: COVID-19 LOGIC - myndighetsinitativ för lokal klimatanpassning
COVID-19 Local Government Initiative on Climate Change (LoGIC)

description.narrative:
Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 Programmet strävar efter att minska effekterna av klimatförändringar i Bangladesh. IPCC(International Panel on Climate Change) rankar Bangladesh som det sjätte mest utsatta landet i världen för klimatförändringar och det land som är mest utsatt för höjningen av havsnivån (undantaget små ö-riken). Förändringar av nederbörden förväntas leda till både fler och svårare översvämningar samt till perioder av torka i vissa områden. Inträngning av havsvatten samt fler och kraftigare cykloner ökar risken för förhöjd saltkoncentration i mark, floder och grundvattnet. Bangladesh regering uppskattar att de fem största naturkatastroferna sen 1998 har minskat BNP med 15%. Återkommande katastrofer har störst påverkar på den fattigaste delen av befolkningen och bidrar till en i vissa områden cementerad fattigdomsproblematik.
Bangladesh har varit ett föregångsland när det gällde att ta fram strategiska planer för att möta klimathotet (ex. National Adaptation Plan of Action - NAPA och Bangladesh Climate Change Strategy and Action Plan - BCCSAP) och att utveckla en nationell finansieringsmekanism för klimatanpassning (Bangladesh Climate Change Trust Fund - BCCTF) men trots att lokala initiativ för klimatanpassning identifieras som ett prioriterat område i både BCCSAP och NAPA så har endast en liten del av öronmärkta resursers implementerats av lokala myndigheter. Lokala klimatanpassningsprojekt som genomförs med en förankring hos befolkningen kan med relativt små medel minska utsattheten hos sårbara delar av befolkningen och medför ofta mindre risker än storskaliga infrastruktursatsningar.
UNDP och UNCDF har gemensamt utvecklat programmet (LoGIC) som avser att stärka lokala myndigheters kapacitet att integrera klimatanpassning i lokala utvecklingsplaner, förbättra nationella mekanismer för lokal klimatfinansiering och implementera klimatanpassningsåtgärder som har identifierats i samråd mellan lokala myndigheter och lokalbefolkningen. Civilsamhällets har en viktig funktion när det kommer till att mobilisera lokalbefolkningen och verka för transparens och ansvarsutkrävande gentemot lokal myndigheter och har därför en tydlig roll i programmet.
Programmet pågår under 48 månader och har en budget på c:a USD 20 milj., Sidas bidrag uppgår till 85 milj. kr vilket motsvarar ungefär hälften av programbudgeten och EU har redan beslutat om ett stöd på € 8 miljoner. Programmet är fullfinansierat men möjligheten finns att skala upp programmet om ytterligare givare skulle ansluta. Programmets övergripande mål är att stärka finansieringsmekanismer och planeringsprocesser för att möjliggöra implementering av klimatfinansiering av lokala myndigheter som förväntas att bidra till fattigdomsbekämpning och minskad utsatthet hos den fattigare delen av befolkningen. C:a 60% av budget avser bidrag till lokala myndigheter och bidrag direkt till utsatta hushåll för genomförandet av resilienshöjande åtgärder. Bidragsdelen uppskattas gynna 200 000 utsatt hushåll i 72 Union Parishad, i 7 Distrikt, som har bedömts vara mycket utsatta för klimatförändringar och ha en stor fattigdomsproblematik.
Division of Local Government (LGD) under Ministry of Local Government, Rural Development and Cooperatives kommer att ha det övergripande ansvaret för genomförandet av programmet enligt en etablerad samarbetsform mellan UNDP och Bangladsh regering. En styrgrupp för projektet kommer att tillsättas med deltagare från Ministry of Planning, Ministry of Disaster Management and Relief, finansministeriet, miljöministeriet, och andra berörda departement. Strygruppenkommer att ansvara för övergirpande syryning av programmet och godkänna projektplaner. UNDP och UNCDF kommer tillsammans hantera en Project Management Unit bestående av nationell och internationell personal för att stödja LGD i genomförandet av programmet under ledning av en National Project Director.

Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 The project will address climate change impact in Bangladesh. The Government of Bangladesh already recognises the severity of climate change and therefore, the related concerns are being gradually mainstreamed in the national development policy planning and financing. The Government has formulated a national action plan (BCCSAP) that provides core programme direction. However, this sector is served by a number of sectoral policies which also shape the expenditure pattern in the national budget. While the local government institutions (LGIs) are mandated to implement many actions related to climate effects, these actions need to be included in the local plans as climate proofing initiatives. The proposed programme will address gaps at local and national levels based on which the results have been designed. At the local level, despite being a repository of local knowledge and information, the LGIs fall short of harnessing the potentials from the local community. The mechanism for formulation of the Local Development Plans (LDP) has scope to engage the poor and vulnerable groups in a participatory way to reflect their climate-related needs and demands. Communities and households face difficulties in securing access to the planning and financing mechanism for sustainable development solutions. On the other hand, the Civil Society Organizations (CSOs) and local institutions who have long been functioning at local level for enhanced participation and accountability also shy off the process owing to lack of appropriate capacity. An in-depth analysis of the potentials and the gaps was carried out to identify the intervention areas at the local level. The duration of the programme is 4 years, 2016-2020, with a total budget of US$ 20.0 million and a planned contribution of approximately USD 10 million (85 million SEK) by Sida and an already approved contribution of € 8 million by the EU. The project will enhance the capacity of vulnerable communities, local government institutions and civil society organisations for planning and financing climate change adaptation solutions in selected climate vulnerable areas. By achieving the objectives and results, the project will contribute to the reduction of poverty and vulnerability in Bangladesh. This is expected to to result in:-Strengthened capacity of vulnerable people and local stakeholders for accountable planning and financing on Climate Change Adaptation/Disaster Risk Reduction actions for building resilience.-Enhanced access of LGIs and vulnerable households to climate funds have for climate resilient infrastructures and adaptive livelihoods.-Established evidence based advocacy for a mechanism for financing local resilience.The programme is designed to benefit roughly 200,000 most vulnerable households in 72 unions in seven districts. The benefits are expected to come out of climate change adaptation actions at various levels, scaled up through local government institutions incorporating high quality accountability and participation of the most vulnerable people. The Local Government Division (LGD) of the Ministry of Local Government Rural Development and Cooperatives will be the implementing agency and will assume overall responsibility for management and implementation of the project in a manner consistent with GoB and UNDP polices. A Project Steering Committee (PSC) will be formed with the participation of Ministry of Planning, Ministry of Disaster Management and Relief , Ministry of Finance, Ministry Environment and Forest, and other relevant ministries. The PSC will be responsible for consensus management decisions for the project when guidance is required, including approval of project plans and revisions. UNDP and UNCDF will jointly manage a Project Management Unit comprised of national and international staff members to support the LGD to implement the project, under the guidance of National Project Director.

tag.narrative: 13.1 - Strengthen resilience and adaptive capacity to climate-related hazards and natural disasters in all countries.
13.1 - Stärka motståndskraften mot och förmågan till anpassning till klimatrelaterade faror och naturkatastrofer i alla länder.

13.3 - Förbättra utbildningen, medvetenheten och den mänskliga och institutionella kapaciteten vad gäller begränsning av klimatförändringarna, klimatanpassning, begränsning av klimatförändringarnas konsekvenser samt tidig varning.
13.3 - Improve education, awareness-raising and human and institutional capacity on climate change mitigation, adaptation, impact reduction and early warning.
16.7 - Ensure responsive, inclusive, participatory and representative decision-making at all levels.
16.7 - Säkerställa ett lyhört, inkluderande, deltagandebaserat och representativt beslutsfattande på alla nivåer.

2.4 - By 2030, ensure sustainable food production systems and implement resilient agricultural practices that increase productivity and production, that help maintain ecosystems, that strengthen capacity for adaptation to climate change, extreme weather, drought, flooding and other disasters and that progressively improve land and soil quality.

2.4 - Senast 2030 uppnå hållbara system för livsmedelsproduktion samt införa motståndskraftiga jordbruksmetoder som ökar produktiviteten och produktionen, som bidrar till att upprätthålla ekosystemen, som stärker förmågan till anpassning till klimatförändringar, extrema väderförhållanden, torka, översvämning och andra katastrofer och som successivt förbättrar mark- och jordkvaliteten.

5.4 - Erkänna och värdesätta obetalt omsorgs- och hushållsarbete genom att tillhandahålla offentliga tjänster, infrastruktur och socialt skydd samt genom att främja delat ansvar inom hushållet och familjen, i enlighet med vad som är nationellt lämpligt.

5.4 - Recognize and value unpaid care and domestic work through the provision of public services, infrastructure and social protection policies and the promotion of shared responsibility within the household and the family as nationally appropriate.

6.4 - By 2030, substantially increase water-use efficiency across all sectors and ensure sustainable withdrawals and supply of freshwater to address water scarcity and substantially reduce the number of people suffering from water scarcity.

6.4 - Till 2030 väsentligt effektivisera vattenanvändningen inom alla sektorer samt säkerställa hållbara uttag och en hållbar försörjning med sötvatten för att angripa vattenbristen och väsentligt minska det antal människor som lider av vattenbrist.

9.1 - Bygga ut tillförlitlig, hållbar och motståndskraftig infrastruktur av hög kvalitet, inklusive regional och gränsöverskridande infrastruktur, för att stödja ekonomisk utveckling och människors välbefinnande, med fokus på ekonomiskt överkomlig och rättvis tillgång för alla.

9.1 - Develop quality, reliable, sustainable and resilient infrastructure, including regional and transborder infrastructure, to support economic development and human well-being, with a focus on affordable and equitable access for all.
